By the science of horoscopy and the science of machines, the examination of the good and bad results of astrology, and the method of destroying enemies, and by the emperor, the destruction of the barbarian religion, in the twelve parts of the five-island continent, the arrival of the emperor and the description of the beginning, together with the completion of the first chapter, occur. The first verse of the chapter on inner science is present because of the statement of acceptance in the request and explanation.

analyzed: paṭale smin ślokāḥ sapta sagraha samūhaḥ ca asti
translated: In this chapter, there are seven verses and a group of seven.

original: kāyavākcittodbhavaduḥkhasamudayanirodhamārganirdeśasagrahādibhiḥ garbhāvasthāyā śukraśoṇitayormelanādārabhya buddhiprāpti yāvat kāyasya sampannatāvidhiḥ / samudayasatyasagraheṇa sampannakāye nāḍīvāyutilakānā yathāsthitividhiḥ /
analyzed: kāya vāc citta udbhava duḥkha samudaya nirodha mārga nirdeśa sagraha ādibhiḥ garbha avasthāyā śukra śoṇitayoḥ melanāt ārabhya buddhi prāpti yāvat kāyasya sampannatā vidhiḥ samudaya satya sagraheṇa sampanna kāye nāḍī vāyu tilakānā yathāsthiti vidhiḥ
translated: By the description of the origin of body, speech, and mind, suffering, origin, cessation, and path, and so on, the method of the completion of the body, starting from the union of semen and blood in the embryonic state up to the attainment of intelligence, and by the group of the truth of origin, the method of the arrangement of the channels and winds in the completed body.
The emperor, the barbarian age, the wheel of time, the lineage of the family, and so on.

original: udbhūtasagraheṇa kāye bāhyābhyantaraparadharmāṇām abhinnatāyāḥ pūrṇanirdeśaḥ / nāḍīuccheda kṣaya 🔽mṛtyulakṣaṇasagraheṇa sampannakāyasya mṛtyusūcanā nirdeśaḥ / jagadutpādanirodhahetubhūtam ekakṣaṇalakṣaṇa / kālacakranirdeśasagraheṇa mṛtyunirdeśaḥ rasāyanādiḥ /
analyzed: udbhūta sa graheṇa kāye bāhya abhyantara para dharmāṇām abhinna tāyāḥ  mṛtyu lakṣaṇa sagraheṇa sampanna kāyasya mṛtyu sūcanā nirdeśaḥ jagat utpāda nirodha hetu bhūtam ekakṣaṇa lakṣaṇa kālacakra nirdeśa sagraheṇa mṛtyu nirdeśaḥ rasāyana ādiḥ
translated: By the collection of the arising of the body, the complete instruction on the non-difference of external and internal phenomena of others is given. By the collection of the signs of the cutting off of the channels, decay, and death, the instruction on the indication of death for one who has a complete body is given. By the collection of the instruction on the wheel of time, which is the cause of the origination and cessation of the world and has the characteristic of a single moment, the indication of death is given, along with elixirs and so on.

original: niyatabālasantatisagraheṇa mṛtyulakṣaṇa mṛtyuhetu ca jñātvā mṛtyorūparyutthānasya vidhiḥ /
analyzed: niyata bāla santati sa graheṇa mṛtyu lakṣaṇa mṛtyu hetu ca jñātvā vidhiḥ
translated: By the collection of the definite continuity of childhood, having known the signs of death and the cause of death, the method of rising above death is taught.

analyzed: sva para darśanayoḥ mīmāsayā samyak mārge praveśa vidhiḥ ca iti dvitīya adhyātma paṭale nyarūpyanta
translated: The investigation of one's own and others' views, and the method of entering the true path, were described in the second chapter on inner principles.

original: abhiṣekapaṭalam prathamaḥ ślokaḥ pūrvapaṭalānusāreṇa abhyarthanāyā vyākhyānokteśca vartate /
analyzed: abhiṣeka paṭalam prathamaḥ ślokaḥ pūrva paṭala anusāreṇa abhyarthanāyāḥ vyākhyāna ukteḥ ca vartate
translated: The first verse of the chapter on consecration is present due to the sequence of the previous chapters and the statement of explanation in the request.

analyzed: atra sapta sagrahāḥ santi
translated: Here there are seven collections.

analyzed: ācārya ādi sarva karma prasara sādhana upāya lakṣaṇa sa graheṇa ācārya śiṣyayoḥ lakṣaṇam
translated: By the collection of the characteristics of the means of accomplishment of the flow of all actions such as the teacher and so on, the characteristics of the teacher and the disciple are taught.

original: ācāryeṇa parārthasādhanārtha sarvakarmaprasarasya lakṣaṇamavabodhya śiṣyasagrahakaraṇam bhūmigrahaṇavidhiśca /
analyzed: ācāryeṇa sarva karma prasarasya lakṣaṇam avabodhya śiṣya sagraha karaṇam bhūmi grahaṇa vidhiḥ ca
translated: The teacher, for the sake of accomplishing the welfare of others, having understood the characteristics of the spread of all actions, the means of attracting disciples and the method of selecting the site.

analyzed: maṇḍala lekhana vidhi sagraheṇa bhūmi gṛhītvā maṇḍala lekhana vidhiḥ
translated: Having selected the site by the means of drawing the maṇḍala, the method of drawing the maṇḍala.

analyzed: maṇḍala abhiṣeka sagraheṇa likhita maṇḍale bāla śiṣya praveśaḥ sapta abhiṣeka vidhiḥ ca
translated: Having drawn the maṇḍala by the means of consecrating the maṇḍala, the entry of the young disciples into the drawn maṇḍala and the method of the seven consecrations.
By the method of the assembly wheel consecration.

analyzed: yoga caryā sagraheṇa abhiṣikta śiṣyasya ācārya tve
translated: By the means of practicing yoga, the disciple who has been consecrated becomes established in the state of a teacher.

analyzed: kāya vāc citta nāmake āśraya traye ca
translated: And is established in the three bases called body, speech, and mind.

analyzed: uttara abhiṣekaḥ gaṇa cakram
translated: The higher consecration is the assembly wheel.

analyzed: mudrā
translated: The mudrā.

analyzed: dṛṣṭiḥ visarjanam
translated: The view. The dismissal.

original: vīrotsavasagraheṇa āvaśyakamudrādṛṣṭiabhiṣekādīni tato maṇḍalavisarjanavīrotsavanirdeśābhyā saha paṭalamida sampannatāmāpnoti /
analyzed: vīrotsava sagraheṇa āvaśyaka mudrā dṛṣṭi abhiṣeka ādīni tatas maṇḍala visarjana vīrotsava nirdeśābhyā saha paṭalam idam sampanna tām āpnoti
translated: By the means of the hero's feast, the necessary mudrās, views, consecrations, and so on, then this chapter attains completion together with the dismissal of the maṇḍala and the instruction on the hero's feast.

analyzed: sādhanā paṭalam prathamaḥ ślokaḥ abhyarthanā vyākhyāna arthayoḥ svīkāra uktiḥ
translated: The first verse is the statement of acceptance of the purpose and the explanation of the request.

original: dvitīyaśloke bhagavato viśuddhikāya samupavarṇya pañcasagrahaistasya sādhana vidhāya tatprakāśaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: dvitīya śloke bhagavataḥ viśuddhikāya samupavarṇya pañca sagrahaiḥ tasya tad prakāśaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: In the second verse, having described the pure body of the Lord, its accomplishment is stated by five chapters, and its manifestation is made.

analyzed: sthāna rakṣā pāpa prāyaścitta ādi sa graheṇa
translated: The place of accomplishment is established by the chapter on protecting the place, repenting sins, and so on.

analyzed: vighna rakṣā puṇya sampanna vidhiḥ ca
translated: The protection from obstacles and the method of accumulating merit.

original: utpattikramaḥ samvṛttisagraheṇa śūnyatāto garbhadhāraṇavidhiḥ utpattikramaḥ maṇḍalarājāgraśca /
analyzed: utpatti kramaḥ samvṛtti sagraheṇa śūnyatātaḥ garbha dhāraṇa vidhiḥ utpatti kramaḥ maṇḍalarāja agraḥ ca
translated: The sequence of birth is by the chapter on conventional truth, the method of bearing the embryo from emptiness, the sequence of birth, and the foremost of the mandala kings.

analyzed: prāṇa deva utpatti sagrahābhyām garbhāt bahis niṣkramaṇam
translated: The going forth from the womb outside by the two chapters on the birth of the life-force and the gods.

analyzed: pratipādanam
translated: The teaching of the signs of the perfection of the sequence of birth.

original: utpattiniṣpannakramābhyām utpattyanantara varṣā''yuṣaḥ sukhānubhūtikrameṇa cittijñānayoḥ sampannatārtha tilakaḥ sūkṣmayogaśca /
analyzed: utpatti niṣpanna kramābhyām utpatti anantara varṣa āyuṣaḥ sukha anubhūti krameṇa citti jñānayoḥ tilakaḥ sūkṣma yogaḥ ca
translated: The tilaka and subtle yoga of the perfection of the mind and knowledge by the sequences of birth and completion, and by the sequence of experiencing happiness in the life of a hundred years after birth.

original: vibhinnakarmasagraheṇa varṣīyā'vasthānantara putraputryorūtpādanavat prāṇapratibimba viṣpādya vibhinnakarmaṇā sādhanopāyikāyāḥ pratipādanam kṛtamasti /
analyzed: vibhinna karma sagraheṇa
translated: The teaching of the means of accomplishment by different karma to the one who has produced the reflection of the life-force like the production of a son and daughter after the stage of a hundred years is done by the chapter on different karma.

analyzed: jñāna paṭalam atra vidyate
translated: The chapter on knowledge here consists of four collections.

analyzed: prathama śloke abhyarthanā vyākhyānayoḥ svīkāra uktiḥ asti
translated: In the first verse, there is a statement of acceptance of the request and explanation.

original: tadanantara kramaśaḥ / yoginītantrādinirmāṇasagrahe skandhaāyatanasamastadhātūśca nirākṛtya āśrayāśritadevamaṇḍalavidhirvarṇitaḥ /
analyzed: kramaśas yoginītantra ādinirmāṇa sagrahe skandha āyatana samasta dhātūḥ ca nirākṛtya āśraya āśrita deva maṇḍala vidhiḥ varṇitaḥ
translated: After that, in order, in the collection of the creation of the Yoginī Tantra and so on, having refuted the aggregates, sense bases, and all elements, the method of the mandala of the deity of the dependent and the supported is described.

original: kāyacatuṣṭayādiviśuddhaniyatasagraheṇa nirāvaraṇasya kāyacatuṣṭayasya jñānasya caturthābhiṣekākṣarajñānayoḥ pratipādana vihitamasti /
analyzed: kāya catuṣṭaya ādi viśuddha niyata sagraheṇa nirāvaraṇasya kāya catuṣṭayasya jñānasya caturtha abhiṣeka akṣara jñānayoḥ pratipādana vihitam asti
translated: In the collection of the definite purification of the four bodies and so on, the teaching of the knowledge of the four bodies without obstruction and the knowledge of the fourth consecration and the syllable is made.

original: vibhinnavinayopāyasagraheṇa bodhi prāptyanantara tattvānā hitakaraṇavidhi lakṣayitum anekasāmānyāsāmānyasādhanopāyikānā pratipādana jātam /

translated: In the collection of the various methods of discipline, in order to indicate the method of benefiting beings after attaining enlightenment, the teaching of the various means of accomplishing the general and specific is made.

original: ante upasahārarūpeṇa ślokadaśakamasti eṣu kālacakrasya śāsturguṇāḥ sagrahattvasya sagrahavidhiścābhihitāḥ /

translated: At the end, there are ten verses in the form of a conclusion, in which the qualities of the teacher Kālacakra and the method of his collection are stated.

analyzed: yaḥ ca mūla tantrataḥ sa gṛhītaḥ na asti
translated: What is not included in the root tantra.

original: koṅṭulanāmakena bhoṭācāryeṇa kālacakrīyābhidheyaḥ vyañjanānā śodhanārtha sagraheṣu tathā'nuvyañjanānā pariśodhanārtha sthāneṣu vyabhāji
analyzed: koṅṭula nāmakena bhoṭa ācāryeṇa kālacakrīya abhidheyaḥ vyañjanānā śodhana artha sa graheṣu tathā anuvyañjanānā pariśodhana artha sthāneṣu vyabhāji
translated: The Tibetan teacher named Koṅṭula divided the consonants for the purpose of purification in the Saṃgrahas and the Anuvyañjanas for the purpose of purification in the Sthānas, under the name Kālacakrīya.

original: ka dvātriśat sagrahāḥ santi nimnāṅkitāḥ / jagaddhātau sagrahāḥ santi /
analyzed: ka dvātriśat sa grahāḥ santi nimna aṅkitāḥ jagaddhātau sa grahāḥ santi
translated: There are thirty-two Saṃgrahas, marked below. In the Jagad-dhātu, there are Saṃgrahas.

analyzed: daśa ākāra vaśīkaraṇa bījasya
translated: The seeds of the ten-fold mastery are H, KṢ, M, L, V, R, Y.

analyzed: śodhana artha samarpitāḥ santi
translated: They are presented for the purpose of purification.

translated: For the purification of the inconceivable world-system, there are Saṃgrahas.🔽In these, six Saṃgrahas are common to the inconceivable world-system for the purpose of purification.🔽In these, six Saṃgrahas are common to the pervasion of the general Tantra. The explanation of the pervaded Tantra-meaning of the external wheel is made by the remaining four Saṃgrahas.

original: adhyātmapaṭale caturmahābhūtasūryacandrarāhudhātūnā pariśodhanārtha ṣaṭsagrahairabhiṣekapaṭalasya pratipādana kṛtamasti /
analyzed: adhyātma paṭale catur mahābhūta sūrya candra rāhu dhātūnā pariśodhana artha ṣaṣ sagrahaiḥ abhiṣeka paṭalasya pratipādana kṛtam asti
translated: And in the chapter on the inner body, the explanation of the consecration chapter is made by the six Saṃgrahas for the purpose of purifying the four great elements, the sun, moon, Rāhu, and the constituents.

original: sādhanāpaṭale pañcajinakulānā pariśodhanārtha pañcasādhanāsagraheṣu vyākhyā kṛtā /
analyzed: sādhanā paṭale pañca jina kulānā pariśodhana artha pañca sādhanā sagraheṣu vyākhyā kṛtā
translated: In the chapter on the means of accomplishment, for the sake of purifying the five buddha families, the explanation is given in the five groups of means of accomplishment.

the accomplishment of the meaning of reality,

The explanation of the six families, the purification of the body of the six families, the five stages of the Guhyasamaja, and the six superknowledges.

analyzed: ānanda garbhasya paramparā ca
translated: The lineage of Ānandagarbha.

original: āryāmnāyaḥ jñānaḍākinīdvārā sarahapādasyopadiṣṭaparamparāyā nāgārjunaāryadevacandrakīrtyādayaḥ pracāra prasārañca kṛtavantaḥ /
analyzed: ārya āmnāyaḥ jñāna ḍākinī dvārā nāgārjuna ārya devacandrakīrti ādayaḥ kṛtavantaḥ
translated: The Ārya tradition was taught by Jñānaḍākinī to Saraha, and was spread by Nāgārjuna, Āryadeva, Candrakīrti, and others.

analyzed: ayam āryaāmnāyaḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: This is called the Ārya tradition.

original: ācāryanāgārjunena guhyasamājasya mūlatantre samāgatotpattikrameṇa sambaddhāni samastatathyānyādāya piṇḍīkṛtasādhanopāyikāyāḥ racanā kṛtā /
analyzed: ācārya nāgārjunena guhya samājasya mūla tantre samāgata utpatti krameṇa sambaddhāni samasta tathyāni ādāya piṇḍīkṛta sādhana upāyikāyāḥ racanā kṛtā
translated: Ācārya Nāgārjuna, having collected all the true teachings connected by the order of origination found in the root tantra of the Guhyasamāja, composed the Piṇḍī-kṛta-sādhana-upayikā.

analyzed: atra guhya samājasya bhāvanā
translated: Here, the meditation on the deity maṇḍala of the Guhyasamāja.

analyzed: tri dhyānam arthāt ādi yoga dhyāna
translated: The three meditations are, in fact, the Ādi-yoga meditation.

analyzed: maṇḍala rāja gradhyāna
translated: The meditation on the king of maṇḍalas.

analyzed: ca vidhinā kriyate
translated: The meditation on the king of actions. The procedure is performed.

original: piṇḍīkṛtasādhanopāyikā deva prabhāsvare vilīya punarūtpannakaraṇasya vidhirapūrṇo'sti /
analyzed: piṇḍīkṛta sādhana upāyikā deva prabhāsvare vilīya vidhiḥ apūrṇaḥ asti
translated: In the Piṇḍī-kṛta-sādhana-upayikā, the deity dissolves into light and the procedure of arising again is not complete.

analyzed: tad pūrtaye ācāryeṇa guhya samāja mahā yoga tantra utpāda krama sādhanā sūtra melāpakasya racanā vyadhāyi
translated: For its completion, the teacher composed the composition of the Sutra of the Sequence of Means for the Generation of the Great Yoga Tantra of the Guhyasamaja.

original: niṣpannakramasya sambandhe pañcakramasya bodhicittavivaraṇasya ca tathā sādhakasya paripakvatārtha abhiṣekamaṇḍalābhyā sambaddhasya viśatividheḥ racanā kṛtā /
analyzed: niṣpanna kramasya sambandhe pañca kramasya bodhi citta vivaraṇasya ca tathā sādhakasya paripakva tā artha abhiṣeka maṇḍalābhyā sambaddhasya viśati vidheḥ racanā kṛtā
translated: In the connection of the accomplished sequence, he composed the twenty-fold composition of the Five Stages and the Commentary on the Mind of Enlightenment, as well as the twenty-fold composition connected with the consecration mandala for the purpose of ripening the practitioner.

original: viśatividhirnāgabodhinā racita iti keṣācid viduṣā matamasti /
analyzed: viśati vidhiḥ nāgabodhinā racitaḥ iti keṣācid viduṣā matam asti
translated: Some scholars have the opinion that the twenty-fold composition was composed by Nagabodhi.

original: nāgārjunasya mukhyaśiṣya āryadevaḥ guhyasamājasya niṣpannakrameṇa sambaddham ekādaśaparicchedātmaka caryāmelāpaka pradīpanāmaka grantha racitavān
analyzed: nāgārjunasya mukhya śiṣyaḥ āryadevaḥ guhya samājasya niṣpanna krameṇa sambaddham ekādaśa pariccheda ātmaka caryāmelāpaka pradīpa nāmaka grantha racitavān
translated: Aryadeva, the chief disciple of Nagarjuna, composed a text called the Caryamelāpakapradīpa, consisting of eleven chapters, connected with the accomplished sequence of the Guhyasamaja.
In addition to this, he composed a text called the Cittaviśuddhikaraṇa, which arises from the Cittviveka,

original: māyākāyānnissṛta svādhiṣṭhānakrama tathā prabhāsvarādauttarikam abhisambodhi kramopadeśanāmaka granthamapi vyaracayat /
analyzed: māyā kāyāt nissṛta svādhiṣṭhāna krama tathā prabhāsvarāt auttarikam grantham api vyaracayat
translated: and also a text called the Abhisambodhikramopadeśa, which arises from the Māyādeha and is the sequence of consecration and the subsequent perfect enlightenment.

original: siddhanāgabodhinā piṇḍīkṛtasādhanā pariśodhyaiḥ janmamṛtyu antarābhavaiḥ saha melayitvā devādhiṣṭhānena prabhāsvare praveśavidhi kāyamaṇḍalam maṇḍalarājāgrasya spaṣṭāṅgāni prakāśayatā utpattikrame guhyasamājavyavasthāvalī tathā niṣpannakramasya pratipādanārtha karmāntavibhaṅgaśca prāṇāyi /
analyzed: siddha nāgabodhinā piṇḍīkṛta sādhanā pariśodhyaiḥ janma mṛtyu antarābhavaiḥ saha melayitvā deva adhiṣṭhānena prabhāsvare praveśa vidhi kāya maṇḍalam maṇḍala rāja agrasya spaṣṭa aṅgāni prakāśayatā utpatti krame guhya samāja vyavasthā āvalī tathā niṣpanna kramasya pratipādana artha karmānta vibhaṅgaḥ ca prāṇāyi
translated: Having illuminated the clear limbs of the foremost of mandala kings, in the order of arising, the arrangement of the Guhyasamaja, and likewise, in order to explain the accomplished stage, the division of the concluding rites has been taught.

analyzed: ācārya rāhula dhara śrī mitreṇa yugala ānanda prakāśa nāma prakriyā racitā
translated: The procedure named Illumination of the Couple's Bliss was composed by the two, the teacher Rahulabhadra and Shrimitra.

original: yaścāryaāmnāyasya maṇḍalavidheḥ prāmāṇikaḥ pūrṇaśca grantho vidyate /
analyzed: yaḥ ca ārya āmnāyasya maṇḍala vidheḥ prāmāṇikaḥ pūrṇaḥ ca granthaḥ vidyate
translated: And the complete and authoritative text of the mandala rite of the noble tradition exists.

original: viśatividhinā guhyasamājasyābhiṣeke datte sati agrimau dvau abhiṣeko asyaiva granthasya sahāyatayā prāptavyau bhavataḥ /
analyzed: viśati vidhinā guhya samājasya abhiṣeke datte sati agrimau dvau abhiṣekaḥ asya eva granthasya sahāya tayā prāptavyau bhavataḥ
translated: When the consecration of the Guhyasamaja is given according to the twenty-one procedures, the next two consecrations should be obtained as aids to this very text.

original: ācāryaśākyamitrasya nāmato guhyasamāje kecit svatatragranthā nopalabhyante kintu nāgārjunaracitasya pañcakramasya dvitīyakrame'sya nāma prāpyate
analyzed: ācārya śākyamitrasya nāmataḥ guhya samāje kecid svatatra granthāḥ na upalabhyante kintu nāgārjuna racitasya pañcakramasya nāma prāpyate
translated: Some of the texts composed by the teacher Shakramitra on the Guhyasamaja are not found, but his name is obtained in the second stage of the five stages composed by Nagarjuna.

original: viṣaye'smin bhoṭadeśīyavidvatsu matabhedo'sti /🔽yathā nīlagranthasya blū enalsasya
analyzed: viṣaye smin bhoṭa deśīya vidvatsu mata bhedaḥ asti  yathā nīlagranthasya
translated: There is a difference of opinion among the learned of Tibet regarding this matter.🔽For example, Gosala Mahāmati accepts that the author of the Blue Annals,

original: racayitā gosalo mahodayaḥ ' jñātvā tamevamucyante jñānino bhavapañjarāt ' ityanta nāgārjunasya racanā śeṣastu śākyamitrasya racaneti svīkaroti
analyzed: racayitā gosalaḥ mahodayaḥ jñātvā tam evam ucyante jñāninaḥ bhava pañjarāt
translated: up to the end of Nāgārjuna's composition, is Nāgārjuna, but the rest is the composition of Śākyamitra.

analyzed: lakṣmīkara racitāyāḥ vairocana nāma pañca krama vṛttau nāgārjuna śiṣyeṣu ati tīkṣṇa buddhiḥ āsīt
translated: In the commentary on the five stages named Vairocana composed by Lakṣmīkara, this Śākyamitra was the most intelligent among the disciples of Nāgārjuna.

original: ataḥ prasannatāvaśād anena svīyagranthasya dvitīyakrame nijaśiṣyasya nāmoṭṭaṅkitam vajrāsanapādenāpi cāya siddhānā krame tame sthāne sthāpitastathā jātyā'ya kāṣṭhaharaḥ eva mahāyānīyanāgārjunasya śiṣya iti svīkṛtam /
analyzed: atas prasanna tā vaśāt anena svīya granthasya dvitīya krame nija śiṣyasya nāma uṭṭaṅkitam vajrāsana pādena api siddhānā krame sthāne sthāpitaḥ tathā jātyāya kāṣṭha haraḥ eva mahāyānīya nāgārjunasya śiṣyaḥ iti svīkṛtam
translated: Therefore, out of delight, he mentioned the name of his disciple in the second stage of his composition. Vajrāsana also placed him among the accomplished disciples in that place. He was born as a wood-collector and was accepted as a disciple of the Mahāyānist Nāgārjuna.

original: keṣācid viduṣā matānusāra śākyamitreti nāgārjunasyaiva nāma vidyate /
analyzed: keṣācid viduṣā mata anusāra śākyamitra iti nāgārjunasya eva nāma vidyate
translated: According to the opinion of some scholars, Śākyamitra is the very name of Nāgārjuna.

original: candrakīrtinā eṣā pañcācāryāṇā vicārān utpattikramaniṣpannakramau ca ṣaṭkoṭi caturnayavidhinā'lakṛtya guhyasamāje pradīpodyatana nāmakasya ṭīkāgranthasya racanā akāri /
analyzed: candrakīrtinā eṣā vicārān utpatti krama niṣpanna kramau ca guhya samāje nāmakasya ṭīkā granthasya racanā akāri
translated: Candrakīrti composed this commentary named Pradīpoddyotana on the Guhyasamāja Tantra, having adorned it with the five stages of arising, the perfected stage, and the six parameters and four methods, by the five masters.

analyzed: asmin eva krame āmnāye
translated: In this very sequence, in this tradition,

analyzed: abhayākaraguptena pañcakrama mati ṭīkā candraprabhā
translated: Abhayākara Gupta composed the commentary on the five stages called Candraprabhā.

analyzed: vīryabhadreṇa pañcakramapañjikā pramāṇa artha nāma bhavyakīrtinā pañcakramapañjikā
translated: Vīryabhadra composed the commentary on the five stages named Pramāṇārtha, and Bhavya composed the commentary on the five stages.
Līlāvajra composed the explanation of the five stages.
Samayavajra composed the commentary on the five stages.

analyzed: kāśmīrika lakṣmīkara mahodayena vairocana nāma
translated: The Kashmiri Lakṣmīkara Mahāsukha composed the commentary on the five stages named Vairocana.

analyzed: tathā muni śrī mahodayena manohara ṭippaṇī racitā
translated: Similarly, the sage Śrī Mahāsukha composed the commentary on the five stages called Manoharā Tīkā.

original: etadatiriktamapi āmnāye'smin anekasiddhācāryairhomapūjādikamāśritya pārivārikagranthānā racanā kṛtā /
analyzed: etad atiriktam api āmnāye smin aneka siddha ācāryaiḥ homa pūjā ādikam āśritya racanā kṛtā
translated: In addition to this, many accomplished masters in this tradition composed family texts based on homa, worship, and so on.

analyzed: sakṣepataḥ utpatti kramasya tri dhyānasya
translated: In brief, the three meditations of the arising sequence,

analyzed: niṣpanna kramasya pañca kramasya
translated: and the five stages of the perfected sequence,

analyzed: ca bhāvanā kartā āmnāyaḥ āryaḥ āmnāya iti abhidhīyate
translated: And the one who performs the meditation is the Āmnāya, called the Āryāmnāya.

original: bustonenāryāmnāyasya paramparāyāḥ īdṛśī gaṇanā kṛtāvajradharaḥ bodhisatvamatiratnam /
analyzed: bustonena ārya āmnāyasya paramparāyāḥ īdṛśī gaṇanā kṛtā vajradharaḥ bodhisatva mati ratnam
translated: Bu ston has made this calculation of the lineage of the Āryāmnāya: Vajradhara, Bodhisattva, Mati, Ratnam,

analyzed: nāgārjunaḥ mataṅgaḥ
translated: Nāgārjuna, Mataṅga,

analyzed: tila upa adaḥ
translated: Tilopāda,

analyzed: nāḍa pādaḥ
translated: Nāḍapāda,

analyzed: dharma matiḥ ca
translated: and Dharmatā.

analyzed: ācārya jñāna pāda āmnāyaḥ anayā paramparayā guhya samājasya
translated: The Āmnāya of Ācārya Jñānapāda, through this lineage, of the Guhyasamāja,

analyzed: mūlatantra tvena
translated: considers that root tantra to be the first chapter, and the later tantras

analyzed: vajragarbha alaṅkāram ca vyākhyā tantra tvena āmananti vidvāsaḥ
translated: are considered to be explanatory tantras, such as the Vajra-garbha-alaṅkāra.

original: ācāryajñānapādaḥ mañjuśriyo bhaviṣyavāṇīmupaśrutyoktagranthatrayamavalambya guhyasamāje svatantragranthān viracayya teṣā vistṛtavyākhyām akārṣīt /
analyzed: ācārya jñānapādaḥ mañjuśriyaḥ bhaviṣya vāṇīm upaśrutya ukta grantha trayam avalambya guhya samāje sva tantra granthān viracayya teṣām vistṛta vyākhyām akārṣīt
translated: Ācārya Jñānapāda, having heard the prophecy of Mañjuśrī, relying on the three texts mentioned, composed independent texts on the Guhyasamāja and wrote an extensive commentary on them.

analyzed: ayam eva jñāna pāda āmnāyaḥ abhidhīyate
translated: This is called the Jñānapāda Āmnāya.

analyzed: tasya pramukha granthāḥ santi dvi krama tattva bhāvanā  samantabhadra nāma sādhanā
translated: His principal texts are: The Meditation on the Reality of the Two Stages,🔽The Means of Accomplishment called Samantabhadra,
The Means of Accomplishment of the Four Branches called Samantabhadra,
and the Muktitilaka.

analyzed: ātma sādhana avatāraḥ ca
translated: And the descent of the means of accomplishing the self.

analyzed: asya śiṣyeṣu dīpaṅkara bhadra praśānta mitra rāhula dhara bhadra vajramukha ādayaḥ prasiddhāḥ santi
translated: Among his disciples, Dipankara, Bhadra, Prasantamitra, Rahuladhara, Bhadravajra, Mukha, and others are well-known.

analyzed: nīlagranthe
translated: In the Blue Annals,

original: asyāḥ paramparāyā īdṛśī gaṇanā kṛtā dīpaṅkarabhadraḥ /
analyzed: asyāḥ paramparāyāḥ īdṛśī gaṇanā kṛtā dīpaṅkarabhadraḥ
translated: This lineage is counted as follows: Dipankara Bhadra,

original: ānandagarbhaḥ gaganapādaḥ śāntipādaḥ śraddhākaraḥ padyakarastathā tibbatasya mahānuvādakācāryaḥ ratnabhadraśca /
analyzed: ānandagarbhaḥ gaganapādaḥ śāntipādaḥ śraddhākaraḥ padyakaraḥ tathā tibbatasya mahā anuvādaka ācāryaḥ ratnabhadraḥ ca
translated: Anandagarbha, Gaganapada, Shantipada, Sraddhakara, Padyakara, and the great Tibetan teacher Ratnabhadra.

original: bustonamateācāryāṇā kramaḥ nimnāṅkita mañjubodhaḥ avadhūtapādaḥbuddhaśrījñānaḥ dīpaṅkaraānandagarbhaḥjayavajraḥ śāntipādaḥ śraddhākaraḥ padyakaraḥ /
analyzed: kramaḥ nimna aṅkita mañjubodhaḥ avadhūtapādaḥ buddha śrī jñānaḥ dīpaṅkara ānandagarbhaḥ jayavajraḥ śāntipādaḥ śraddhākaraḥ padyakaraḥ
translated: In the Buston tradition, the sequence of teachers is as follows: Manjuprabha, Avadhutipada, Buddha Shri Jnana, Dipankara, Anandagarbha, Jayavajra, Shantipada, Sraddhakara, Padmakara,

analyzed: ratnabhadraḥ ca
translated: And Ratnabhadra.

original: asminnāmnāye utpattikramasya bhāvanā /🔽catuḥ sevāṅgaiḥ niṣpannakramasya sādhanā /
analyzed: asmin āmnāye utpatti kramasya bhāvanā
translated: In this tradition, the meditation on the sequence of origination is done.🔽The practice of the sequence accomplished by the four limbs of service is done.

analyzed: catur cakreṣu catur tilaka bhāvanā catur ānandānām utpatti krame kriyate sma
translated: The meditation on the four tilakas in the four chakras is done in the sequence of origination of the four joys.

analyzed: āmnāye smin pitṛ tantre pradhāne pi sādhanā paddhatiḥ tathā asya abhiṣeka vidhiḥ mātṛ tantra vat vidyate
translated: In this tradition, even though it is primarily based on the Pitri Tantra, there is a method of accomplishment and a method of consecration like in the Matr Tantra.

original: śāntipādaparamparā śāntipādaḥ mūlatantrottaratantre miśrīkṛtya kusumamañjarīguhyasamājanibandha nāmakasya granthasya racanā vidhāya guhyasamājasya svatantrapaddhatyā vyākhyā cakāra /
analyzed: śāntipāda paramparā śāntipādaḥ mūla tantra uttara tantre miśrīkṛtya kusumamañjarī guhyasamājanibandha nāmakasya granthasya racanā vidhāya guhyasamājasya sva tantra paddhatyā vyākhyā cakāra
translated: Having composed the text named Kusuma-mañjarī-guhyasamāja-bandha by mixing the Śānti-pāda series and the Śānti-pāda of the Mūla-tantra and the Uttara-tantra, he performed the commentary on the Guhyasamāja according to the independent method.

analyzed: anena ārya āmnāyasya ācārya jinaputra bhūmi miśrataḥ tathā jñānapāda paramparāyāḥ ācārya bhaiṣajyataḥ guhya samājasya adhyayana kṛtam
translated: By this, he studied the Guhyasamāja from Ārya-āmnāya, Ācārya-jinaputra-bhūmi-miśra, and Jñāna-pāda-paramparā, and from Ācārya-bhaisajya.

original: kintvanenāmnāyadvayena bhinnāyā akṣobhya kulamaṇḍalānā paramparāyāḥ sthāpanā kṛtā darśane'pi mādhyamikadarśanāpekṣayā vijñānavādinaḥ anusṛtāḥ /
analyzed: kintu anena āmnāya dvayena bhinnāyāḥ kula maṇḍalānā paramparāyāḥ sthāpanā kṛtā darśane api mādhyamika darśana apekṣayā vijñāna vādinaḥ anusṛtāḥ
translated: However, by these two traditions, he established the unbroken lineage of the Akṣobhya-kula-maṇḍalas, and even in the view, he followed the Vijñānavādins in relation to the Madhyamaka view.

analyzed: ittham iyam ekā svatantra paramparā vidyate
translated: Thus, this is one independent lineage.

original: ācāryalalitavajrasya paramparā asya paramparā guhyasamāje nidānaparivartasya mātṛtantrasyānusāra vyākhyā karoti /
analyzed: ācārya lalitavajrasya paramparā asya paramparā guhya samāje nidāna parivartasya mātṛtantrasya anusāra vyākhyā karoti
translated: The lineage of Ācārya Lalitavajra. This lineage is explained in accordance with the nidāna chapter of the Guhyasamāja, which is a mother tantra.

analyzed: ittham iyam api ekā svatantra paramparā tvena svīkṛtā
translated: Thus, this is also accepted as a separate independent lineage.

original: paṇḍitasmṛtijñānaparamparā paṇḍitasmṛtijñānena gurūbhadrapādato guhyasamājasyā'dhyayana kṛtantathā'nyaparamparāto bhinnā svatantrā vyākhyā sādhanāpaddhateśca sthāpanā kṛtā /
analyzed: paṇḍita smṛti jñāna paramparā paṇḍita smṛti jñānena guru ubhadrapādataḥ guhya samājasya adhyayana bhinnā svatantrā vyākhyā sādhanā paddhateḥ ca sthāpanā kṛtā
translated: The lineage of scholar Smṛtijñānakīrti. Scholar Smṛtijñānakīrti studied the Guhyasamāja from Guru Bhadra and other lineages, and composed an independent commentary and a method of practice.

analyzed: tibbatam api gatavān āsīt
translated: He also went to Tibet.

analyzed: svayam anena bhoṭa bhāṣāyā ṣaḍaṅga yoga vyākhyā ādeḥ anuvādaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: He himself translated the commentary on the six-limbed yoga and other texts into the Tibetan language.

original: kālacakravyākhyānusāreṇa guhyasamājaparamparā nālandāyāḥ naḍapādādiṣaḍdvārapālānāmāgamanāntara śambhalataḥ kālacakrasyāryadeśe pracāro'bhūt prāyeṇānuttaratantrasya kālacakrapaddhatyā vyākhyā prārabdhā /
analyzed: kālacakra vyākhyā anusāreṇa guhya samāja paramparā nālandāyāḥ naḍapāda ādi ṣaṣ dvārapālānām āgamana antara śambhalataḥ kālacakrasya ārya deśe pracāraḥ bhūt prāyeṇa anuttara tantrasya kālacakra paddhatyā vyākhyā prārabdhā
translated: In accordance with the explanation of the Kālacakra, the lineage of the Guhyasamāja spread in the noble land of India from Śambhala after the arrival of the six gate-keepers of Nālandā beginning with Naḍapāda. The explanation of the unsurpassed tantra was mostly begun with the Kālacakra method.

analyzed: eṣu guhya samājaḥ tathā sthāpanā vidhiḥ āste
translated: Among these, the Guhyasamāja and the method of establishing the celestial maṇḍalas remain.

original: ānandagarbhaparamparā vajratattvasvarūpāt jahorarājñaḥ prakāśacandrāt ānandagarbheṇāṣṭadaśatantrasyādhyayana kṝtam /
analyzed: ānandagarbha paramparā vajra tattva svarūpāt jahora rājñaḥ prakāśacandrāt ānandagarbheṇa aṣṭadaśa tantrasya adhyayana
translated: The lineage of Ananda-garbha, having studied the eighteen tantras from the Vajra-tattva-svarupa, the son of Jahorara-raja, composed this.

analyzed: ime tārayā adhiṣṭhitāḥ āsan
translated: These were blessed by Tara.

original: anena guhyasamājamūlatantra vairocanamāyājālamūlatantra vyākhyātantra ca yogatantrīyatattvasagrahasya prathamadhātubhāgataḥ sayukto rakṣācakravidhistathā mahāmudrātaḥ mudrayitvā bhāvanāvidheranusaraṇa kurvatā guhyasamājasya vyākhyā yogatantrapaddhatyā kṛtā /
analyzed: anena ca yogatantrīya tattva sagrahasya prathama dhātu bhāgataḥ sa yuktaḥ rakṣā cakra vidhiḥ tathā mahāmudrātaḥ mudrayitvā bhāvanā vidheḥ anusaraṇa kurvatā guhya samājasya vyākhyā yogatantra paddhatyā kṛtā
translated: By this, the Guhyasamaja Mula Tantra, the Vairocana Maya Jala Mula Tantra, the Vyakhyata Tantra, and the Yoga Tantra Iti Tattva Sangraha's first chapter part, along with the Raksha Chakra Vidhi, and the Mahamudra, having been sealed, by following the Bhavana Vidhi, the explanation of the Guhyasamaja was done by the Yoga Tantra Padhati.

original: etadanusāra guhyasamājasya deśanā śāsturnirvāṇāt satāhānantara kṛtāsīt /
analyzed: etad anusāra guhya samājasya deśanā śāstuḥ nirvāṇāt kṛtā āsīt
translated: In accordance with this, the teaching of the Guhyasamaja was done one hundred years after the passing away of the Teacher.

original: tadanantara yāvantastantraśāstrasyopadeśā jātāste sarve vyākhyātantratvena svīkriyante /
analyzed: yāvantaḥ tantra śāstrasya upadeśāḥ jātāḥ te sarve vyākhyā tantra tvena svīkriyante
translated: After that, all the teachings of the Tantra Shastra that occurred are accepted as Vyakhyata Tantras.

original: itthamāryāvarte guhyasamājayogatantrasamāveśāt guhysamājasya vyākhyākaraṇasya pādhatyā saha guhyasamājasya sapta pramukhāḥ paramparāḥ āsan /
analyzed: ittham ārya āvarte guhya samāja yoga tantra samāveśāt guhya samājasya vyākhyā karaṇasya pādhatyā saha guhya samājasya sapta pramukhāḥ paramparāḥ āsan
translated: Thus, in Āryāvarta, due to the inclusion of the Guhyasamāja Yoga Tantra, seven main lineages of the Guhyasamāja arose along with the explanation of the Guhyasamāja.

original: jñeyakośe koṅṭulamahodayenāryadeśe guhyasamājasya paramparāṇā sattā svīkṛtā /🔽tāsumahāpadyavajraanaṅgavajranāgārjunalīlāvajravajrahāsatrikaṇṭheśvarasughoṣarakṣitabuddhajñānaratnākaraśāntipādaānandagarbhādīnā paramparāḥ pramukhāḥ āsan /
analyzed: jñeyakośe koṅṭula mahodayena ārya deśe guhya samājasya paramparāṇā sattā svīkṛtā  tāsu mahāpadya vajra anaṅga vajranāgārjuna līlāvajra vajrahāsa trikaṇṭha īśvara sughoṣa rakṣita buddha jñāna ratnākara śāntipāda ānandagarbha ādīnā paramparāḥ pramukhāḥ āsan
translated: In the Jñeyakośa, the existence of the lineages of the Guhyasamāja in the Āryadeśa is accepted by the great ocean of Koṅkaṇa.🔽Among them, the main lineages were those of Mahāpadmavajra, Anangavajra, Nāgārjuna, Līlāvajra, Vajrahāsa, Trikaṇṭheśvara, Sughoṣarākṣita, Buddhajñānaratnākara, Śāntipāda, Ānandagarbha, and others.

original: tibbate ābhyaḥ paramparābhya āryanāgārjunajñānapādaśaktipādavajrahāsapadyavajra ānandagarbhādīnā paramparāḥ samāgatā āsan /
analyzed: ābhyaḥ paramparābhyaḥ ārya nāgārjuna jñānapāda śaktipāda vajra hāsapadya vajra ānandagarbha ādīnā paramparāḥ samāgatāḥ āsan
translated: In Tibet, from those lineages, the lineages of Āryadeva, Nāgārjuna, Jñānapāda, Śaktipāda, Vajrahāsa, Padmāvajra, Ānandagarbha, and others came together.

analyzed: tāsu ārya āmnāya jñāna pādayoḥ parampare prāmukhyeṇa āstām
translated: Among them, the lineages of Ārya and Amnaya and Jñānapāda were mainly present.

original: kṛṣṇamāritantrasya parampara asya tantrasya pracāra prasāra ca jñeyakośe kālapañcake vibhajya spaṣṭīkṛtametat /
analyzed: kṛṣṇamāri tantrasya asya tantrasya pracāra prasāra ca jñeya kośe kāla pañcake vibhajya spaṣṭīkṛtam etat
translated: The lineage of the Kṛṣṇayamāritantra and the spread of this tantra are clearly divided and explained in the Jñeyakośa in the five ages.

original: yaditthamtṛtīyasaṅgīteḥ kiñcit samayānantara kṛṣṇayamāritantrasya pracāro jātaḥ /
analyzed: yat ittham tṛtīya saṅgīteḥ kiñcid samaya anantara kṛṣṇayamāri tantrasya pracāraḥ jātaḥ
translated: If it is so, then after some time, the spread of the Kṛṣṇayamāritantra of the third Saṃgīti took place.

analyzed: yaḥ ca barṣa yāvat āsīt
translated: And it lasted for a year.

analyzed: ayam eva siddhi kālaḥ iti ucyate
translated: This is called the period of accomplishment.

analyzed: vibhinna caryāṇā prāpti kālaḥ barṣa yāvat pracalitaḥ
translated: The period of attainment of the various practices lasted for a year.

analyzed: asmin kāle śāsane
translated: In this period, in the teachings

original: aneke'ntarāyāḥ samāpatitāḥ tatraivāneke siddhapurūṣā api prādurbhūtāḥ /
analyzed: aneka intarāyāḥ samāpatitāḥ tatra eva aneke siddha purūṣāḥ api prādurbhūtāḥ
translated: many obstacles arose, and many accomplished beings appeared there itself.

analyzed: yaiḥ ca svīya tantra balena janāḥ ākarṣitāḥ
translated: And by whom people were attracted by the power of their own tantras.

analyzed: brāhyaṇa cāṇakya ādayaḥ asmin kāle eva prādurbhūtāḥ
translated: Brāhmaṇa Cāṇakya and others appeared in this period itself.

analyzed: varṣa yāvat āsīt
translated: This period lasted for a year.

original: atra lalitavajrāt kamalarakṣita yāvat samayaḥ samāyāti yaścotpattikramasya siddheḥ caryāyāḥ
analyzed: atra lalitavajrāt kamalarakṣita yāvat samayaḥ samāyāti yaḥ ca utpatti kramasya siddheḥ caryāyāḥ
translated: Here, from Lalitavajra up to Kamalaraṣmi, the time that comes is the period of the accomplishment of the sequence of origination and the practice.

analyzed: kālaḥ iti ucyate
translated: It is called the period.

original: ayamāśikacaryākālaḥ svīkriyate yaśca kamalarakṣitādārabhya vartamānakāla yāvat svīkriyate /
analyzed: ayam āśika caryā kālaḥ svīkriyate yaḥ ca kamalarakṣitāt ārabhya svīkriyate
translated: This is accepted as the period of the practice of the āśīkas, and it is accepted from Kamalaraṣmi up to the present time.

original: sāmānyata uparyuktakāleṣu kṛṣṇayamāritantrasya pracāraḥ prasāraśca jātaḥ /
analyzed: sāmānyatas upari ukta kāleṣu kṛṣṇayamāri tantrasya pracāraḥ prasāraḥ ca jātaḥ
translated: In general, in the above-mentioned periods, the spread and propagation of the Kṛṣṇayamāritantra took place.

original: tatra sāmānyajanamadhye'bhiṣekasya vyākhyānasya ca sarvaprathama śreyaḥ ācāryalalitavajraḥ madhye jñānapādaḥ ante ca brāhyaṇa ācāryaḥ śrīdhara āpnoti /
analyzed: tatra vyākhyānasya ca sarva prathama śreyaḥ ācārya lalitavajraḥ madhye jñānapādaḥ ante ca brāhyaṇa ācāryaḥ śrīdhara āpnoti
translated: Among the general public, the first to receive the consecration and explanation of the tantra were Acharya Lalitavajra, in the middle Jnanapa, and at the end the Brahmin Acharya Shridhara.

original: tatra kṛṣṇayamāriraktayamāribhedayoḥ tattvatrayasyopadeśasya ca paramparāyāḥ samanvayaḥ viśeṣataḥ ācāryaśrīdharasya racanāyāmulabhyate /
analyzed: tatra kṛṣṇa yamāri rakta yamāri bhedayoḥ tattva trayasya upadeśasya ca paramparāyāḥ samanvayaḥ viśeṣataḥ ācārya śrīdharasya racanāyām ulabhyate
translated: In this, the continuity of the teaching of the three principles and the distinction between Krishna Yamari and Rakta Yamari is especially found in the composition of Acharya Shridhara.

original: tathā tata eva bhoṭadeśe asyāḥ paramparāyāḥ sūtrapāto bhavati /
analyzed: tathā tatas eva bhoṭa deśe asyāḥ paramparāyāḥ sūtra pātaḥ bhavati
translated: And from there, the transmission of this lineage occurs in Tibet.

original: prāyaḥ bhoṭadeśe'pi samrājā sroṅcana gampo mahodayena asyā sādhanopāyikāyā racanā kṛtā /
analyzed: prāyas bhoṭadeśe pi samrājā sroṅcana gampaḥ mahodayena asyāḥ sādhana upāyikāyāḥ racanā kṛtā
translated: In Tibet also, the composition of this sadhana was made by the great king Srongtsen Gampo during his great prosperity.

original: yā ca tantrasya savaprathamo granthaḥ svīkriyate /🔽nīlagranthe'bhihita yat sroṅcanaracitayamāritantrasya sādhanā adyāpyupalabhyate /
analyzed: yā ca tantrasya sava prathamaḥ granthaḥ svīkriyate  sādhanā adya api upalabhyate
translated: And it is accepted as the first text of the tantra.🔽It is stated in the Blue Annals that the sadhana of the Yamari Tantra composed by Srongtsen is still available.

original: tārānāthena kṛṣṇayamāritantra lalitavajreṇa janasāmānye ānītam iti svīkṛtam /
analyzed: tārānāthena lalitavajreṇa jana sāmānye ānītam iti svīkṛtam
translated: It is accepted that the Krishna Yamari Tantra was brought to the general public by Tara Natha and Lalitavajra.

analyzed: hevajrasya paramparā dvayam sāmānyatas tantra śāstrasya pradhāna paramparā dvayam upalabhyate
translated: The two lineages of Hevajra In general, the Tantra Shastra has two main lineages:

analyzed: dīrgha paramparā upaparamparā ca
translated: The long lineage and the short lineage.

analyzed: upaparamparā karṇa tantra paramparā tvena vaktu śakyā
translated: The short lineage can be said to be the lineage of the ear.

original: yato hyatra sādhakaḥ kāmapi pūrvaparamparā vināpi iṣṭadevasya arthāt śāstuḥ sākṣātkāra kṛtvā pūrṇatastantraśāstra gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: yatas hi atra sādhakaḥ kām api pūrva paramparā vinā api iṣṭadevasya arthāt śāstuḥ sākṣātkāra kṛtvā pūrṇatas tantra śāstra gṛhṇāti
translated: Because here the practitioner, without any previous lineage, directly perceives the desired deity, that is, the teacher, and fully receives the Tantra Shastra.

analyzed: hevajra tantrasya etādṛś paramparā dvayam upalabhyate
translated: Such a two-fold lineage is found in the Hevajra Tantra.

original: dīrghaparamparā prathamaparicchedānusāra hevajratantrasya deśanā tadā kṛtāsīt yadā tathāgato vajrāsane buddhagayāyā
analyzed: dīrgha paramparā prathama pariccheda anusāra hevajra tantrasya deśanā tadā kṛtā āsīt yadā tathāgataḥ vajrāsane
translated: The long lineage, according to the first chapter, the teaching of the Hevajra Tantra was given when the Tathagata attained enlightenment on the vajra seat at Buddha Gaya.

original: bodhi lebhe tadā śāstā herūkakule'ṣṭamukhasya bhujayuktasya hevajrasya rūpe utpadyate /
analyzed: bodhi lebhe tadā śāstā herūka kula iṣṭa mukhasya bhuja yuktasya hevajrasya rūpe utpadyate
translated: At that time, the teacher appeared in the form of Heruka with eight faces and many arms, as Hevajra.

original: bodhisatvavajragarbhanairātmyābhyā kṛtāyā prārthanāyā vistṛtamūlatantrasya garbha sagṛhya sagrahatantrarūpatvenāsya deśanā karoti /
analyzed: bodhisatva vajragarbha nairātmyābhyā kṛtāyā prārthanāyāḥ vistṛta mūla tantrasya garbha sagṛhya sagraha tantra rūpa tvena asya deśanā karoti
translated: He taught the extensive root Tantra, taking the essence of the request made by the Bodhisattvas Vajragarbha and Nairatmya, in the form of a Tantra with chapters and sections.

original: kecana vidvāso'sya deśanā tuṣitaloke jāteti manyante /
analyzed: kecana vidvāsaḥ asya deśanā tuṣita loke jātā iti manyante
translated: Some scholars think that his teaching began in the Tusita heaven.

analyzed: kecana dhānya kaṭake ca manyante
translated: Some think it was in the Dhānyakataka.

original: jambūdvīpe'sya sarvaprathamaḥ pracāraḥ prasārśca kena kṛtaḥ sambandhe'smin naika matamasti /
analyzed: jambūdvīpe sarva prathamaḥ pracāraḥ prasārḥ ca kena kṛtaḥ sambandhe smin
translated: In Jambudvīpa, who first spread and propagated it? There is no single opinion on this.

original: dagapoṭaśīnamagyalamahodayasya matamasti yad dakṣiṇabhārate aoḍiśinṛpo visukalpaḥ hetulakṣaṇayānasya pāramitānayasya 🔽prakāṇḍapaṇḍita āsīditi /
analyzed: dagapoṭaśīnamagyala mahodayasya matam asti yat dakṣiṇa bhārate aoḍiśi nṛpaḥ visu kalpaḥ hetu lakṣaṇa yānasya pāramitā nayasya  prakāṇḍa paṇḍitaḥ āsīt iti
translated: The opinion of the great sage Dāgaba is that in South India, the king of Aḍīśi, Viśvakalpa, was a great scholar of the philosophy of the Perfection Vehicle.

original: yadā sa sūtreṣu kāmatyāga binā arthāt rāgasya vargīkaraṇaviṣaye likhitāni katipayasūtravacanāni apaśyat tathā tadavagantum utkaṭajijñāsayā praṇidhānamakarot tasmin kāle ḍākinībhirbhaviṣyavāṇī kṛtā yad etad aoḍiyānajñāna ḍākinībhyaḥ prāptu śakyate /
analyzed: yadā sa sūtreṣu kāma tyāga binā arthāt rāgasya vargīkaraṇa viṣaye likhitāni katipaya sūtra vacanāni apaśyat tathā tat avagantum utkaṭa jijñāsayā praṇidhānam akarot tasmin kāle ḍākinībhiḥ bhaviṣya vāṇī kṛtā yat etat aoḍiyāna jñāna ḍākinībhyaḥ prāptu śakyate
translated: When he saw in the sūtras a few statements written about the classification of desire without abandoning desire, and with a strong desire to understand that, he made a vow. At that time, the ḍākinīs made a prophecy that this knowledge of Aḍīśi could be obtained from the ḍākinīs.

original: tadanusāra saḥ aoḍiyānamagāt tatra tantrasādhanā vidhāya siddhilābhamakarot /
analyzed: saḥ aoḍiyānam agāt tatra tantra sādhanāḥ vidhāya siddhi lābham akarot
translated: Accordingly, he went to Aḍīśi, there he performed the practice of the tantra and attained accomplishment.

analyzed: ayam eva sarva prathama tatas hevajra tantram ānītavān
translated: He alone first brought the Hevajra Tantra from there.

analyzed: iyam eva dīrgha paramparā iti ucyate
translated: This is called the long lineage.

analyzed: paramparāyāḥ kramam asthāpayat
translated: Vajradhara, Vajradākinī, Virūpa, Ḍombīpa, Lalitavajra, Vīṇāpāda, Garbhapāda, Peṇḍapāda, Durjayacandra, Vīravāgīśvara, Vajrācārya, and Akṣobhyavajra established this lineage in order.

original: upaparamparā karṇatantraparamparā vā tibbatīya ṅogastonasya dharmakāyavajrasya
analyzed: upa paramparā karṇa tantra paramparā vā dharmakāya vajrasya
translated: The secondary lineage is the lineage of the ear-whispered transmission.

original: matānusāra nāgārjuna eva sarvaprathama hevajravajrapañjaracatuṣpīṭhādīn tālapatre likhitvā aoḍiyānata ānītavāniti /
analyzed: mata anusāra nāgārjunaḥ eva sarva prathama hevajra vajrapañjara catuṣpīṭha ādīn tālapatre likhitvā aoḍiyānataḥ ānītavān iti
translated: According to the view of the Tibetan master Dharmavajra, Nāgārjuna first wrote the Hevajra, Vajrapañjara, Catupitha, and so on on palm leaves and brought them from Oddiyāna.

analyzed: sma luṅ pāda nepālīya ācārya falam thīṅ pādayoḥ matam asti yat sarorūhaḥ kukkurī pādaḥ
translated: The view of the Nepalese master Smṛtijñānakīrti and others is that Saraha, Kukkuripa,

analyzed: guhyacandra tilakāt siddhim upalabhya aoḍiyānataḥ hevajra tantram āmantritavān
translated: having attained accomplishment from the Guhyacandatīkā, invited the Hevajra Tantra from Oddiyāna.

analyzed: tatra aneka sādhana upāyikāḥ ca aracayat
translated: There he composed many means of accomplishment and instructions.

original: mistona puṇyadhvajarampāityanusāreṇa virūpapādaḥ jñānaḍākinībhyaḥ hevajratantra vyākhyātantreṇa sahopalabdhavān asmin viṣaye tena svasavedyanāmakaniṣpannakramanirdeśasya racanā kṛtā /
analyzed: mistona puṇyadhvaja rampāiti anusāreṇa virūpapādaḥ jñāna ḍākinībhyaḥ hevajra tantra vyākhyā tantreṇa saha upalabdhavān asmin viṣaye tena sva savedya nāmaka niṣpanna krama nirdeśasya racanā kṛtā
translated: According to Miston's Punyadhvajarampā, Virūpa obtained this from the Jñānadākinīs along with the explanatory tantra of the Hevajra Tantra. He composed the Nispannakramaniścaya named Svasvedya on this subject.

analyzed: anena indrabhūti mādhyamaḥ api anugṛhītaḥ
translated: By this, Indrabhūti was also favored.

original: keṣācid viduṣā matamasti yat virūpapādaśiṣyeṇa caryāpadena augṛhītasiddha ḍombīpādapūrvarājāna senara damayitvā tataḥ aoḍiyāna gatvā jñānaḍākinīnā parāmarśena kulukullāāśalidvayahevajragarbhatantrāṇyānītāni /
analyzed: keṣācid viduṣā matam asti yat virūpapāda śiṣyeṇa caryāpadena damayitvā tatas aoḍiyāna gatvā jñāna ḍākinīnā parāmarśena kulukullā āśali dvaya hevajragarbha tantrāṇi ānītāni
translated: Some scholars have the opinion that the accomplished Dombipāda, who was instructed by the disciple of Virūpa, the master of conduct, having subdued the king of Oḍiyāna, then went to Oḍiyāna and brought the Hevajragarbhatantra along with the two Kulukullaśalis through the advice of the Jñānadākinīs.

analyzed: tad upari tena racitam
translated: On that basis, he composed the two texts Nairātmyasādhana and Sahajasiddhi.

analyzed: tārānāthena kambala pāda sarorūhābhyām āmantritam asti iti svīkṛtam
translated: It is accepted by Tārānātha that the Hevajra Tantra was requested by Kambalapāda and Sarahapāda.

analyzed: jñeya kośa anusāra hevajrasya bhārata varṣe aneka paramparāḥ āsan
translated: According to the Jñeyakośa, there were many lineages of the Hevajra in the land of India.

analyzed: tāsu paramparāḥ pramukhāḥ āsan
translated: Among them, the main lineages were those of Saroruha, Vajra, Krishna, Samaya, Vajra, Durjaya, Chandra, Ratna, Akarnada, and Maitripa.

analyzed: ṭīkāsu
translated: In the commentaries on Hevajra, there is the commentary on the essential meaning of Hevajra composed by the bodhisattva Vajragarbha.
There is the Pañjikā Padminī of Saroruhavajra.

analyzed: bhavabhadrasya hevajra vyākhyā vivaraṇam
translated: There is the Hevajravyākhyāvivaraṇa of Bhavabhadra.
There is the Pañjikā Yoga Ratna-mālā of Krishna-pāṇḍita.

analyzed: su viśuddha sampuṭaḥ
translated: There is the Suviśuddha-samputa of Daṇḍin.

analyzed: durjaya candrasya pañjikā kaumudī
translated: There is the Pañjikā Kaumudī of Durjaya-candra.

analyzed: sukīrtibhadrasya nāḍapādasya
translated: There is the Naḍapāda of Sukīrti-bhadra.

original: vajrasārasagrahaḥ kṛṣṇapādasya pañjikāsmṛtinipātaḥ padyāṅkuravajrasya hevajratantrarāja ṭīkā /
translated: There is the Vajrasāra-saṃgraha, the Pañjikā Smṛti-nipāta, and the commentary on the Hevajra Tantra-rāja by Padyaṅkura-vajra.
There is the Pañjikā Muktāvalī of Śrī Ratna-akara-śānti-pāda.

analyzed: kāmadhenoḥ pañjikā padya uddharaṇa ādayaḥ ca prasiddhāḥ santi
translated: There are the well-known Pañjikā Padyo-ddhāraṇa and others of Kāmadhenu.

original: ittham etādṛśyaḥ bhāratavarṣe hevajrasya anekaparamparā āsan kintu sādhanāpaddhatau cakrasavaraguhyasamājasamā'sya pṛthak pṛthak svatantraparamparā āsan /
analyzed: ittham etādṛśyaḥ bhārata varṣe hevajrasya aneka paramparāḥ āsan kintu sādhanā paddhatau cakra savara guhya samāja samāsya pṛthak pṛthak svatantra paramparāḥ āsan
translated: Thus, such lineages of Hevajra existed in the land of India, but in the Sadhana Paddhati, there were separate independent lineages of Cakrasamvara and Guhyasamaja.

original: cakrasavarasya paramparā bhāratavarṣe cakrasavaratantrānusāra sādhakasya paripakvatārtha muktyartha cānekasādhanāparamparāṇā vikāso jātaḥ
analyzed: cakrasavarasya paramparā bhārata varṣe cakrasavara tantra anusāra sādhakasya paripakva tā artha mukti artha ca aneka sādhanā paramparāṇā vikāsaḥ jātaḥ
translated: The lineage of Cakrasamvara, in accordance with the Cakrasamvara Tantra, gave rise to many lineages of practice in the land of India for the sake of ripening practitioners and for the sake of liberation.

original: yathādharmarājaprakāśacandreṇa pracāritasya cakrasavarasya ḍākārṇavādhṛtaparamparā siddhaluīpādīyaāmnāyānusāra pradhānībhūta devakulayutānā vyutkramika akrama
analyzed: yathā dharmarāja prakāśacandreṇa pracāritasya cakra savarasya ḍākārṇava ādhṛta paramparā siddhaluīpādīya āmnāya anusāra pradhānībhūta devakula yutānām vyutkramika akrama
translated: The Sadhana Paddhati of the individual, who is the principal one endowed with a temple of the deity, in accordance with the teachings of the Siddha Luipa, who received the lineage from the ocean of Dakara, of the Cakrasamvara propagated by Dharmaraja Prakasacandra, is a gradual and non-gradual

original: pudgalānā sādhanāpaddhatiḥ /🔽ācāryakṛṣṇapādīyaāmnāyānusāra cakrasavarīyadevakulānāmāvirbhāvavidhiḥ /🔽siddhavajrapādīyacakrasavarasya devānām atyantagambhīrakāyamaṇḍalena saha yugapat zhaṭiti
analyzed: sādhanā paddhatiḥ                        siddha vajrapādīya cakra savarasya devānām atyanta gambhīra kāya maṇḍalena saha yugapad
translated: method of practice.🔽The method of manifestation of the Cakrasamvara deities in accordance with the teachings of Acharya Krishnapa.
The method of simultaneously and instantly meditating on the extremely profound body mandala of the Cakrasamvara deities in accordance with the teachings of Siddha Vajrapa.
The lineage of the Cakrasaṃvara Vajra Ocean, following the scriptures of Siddha Lavapa.

original: ācāryanāgārjunasya devānā sādhanāparamparā indrabhūterapi devānā sādhanāparamparā /
analyzed: ācārya nāgārjunasya devānā sādhanā paramparā indrabhūteḥ api devānā sādhanā paramparā
translated: The lineage of the practice of the gods by Ācārya Nāgārjuna, and also the lineage of the practice of the gods by Indra Bhūti.

original: maitrīpādasya evakulayutasya cakrasavarasya sādhanāvidhiḥ ācāryatrinetreṇa sahajasaptamatantramanukṛtya nirmitā sādhanāpaddhatiḥ /
analyzed: maitrīpādasya eva kula yutasya cakra savarasya sādhanā vidhiḥ ācārya trinetreṇa sahaja saptama tantram anukṛtya nirmitā sādhanā paddhatiḥ
translated: The method of practice of the Cakrasaṃvara united with the Hevajra by Maitrīpāda. The manual of practice composed by Ācārya Trilocana, following the Saptati Tantra of Sahaja.

original: tibbate ślokātmakasya paricchedasamvalitasya cakrasavaramūlatantrasyānuvādaḥ sarvaprathama ratnabhadra marado dharmendrābhyā kṛtastadanusāra cakrasavarasya paramparātraya nimnāṅkitamasti /
analyzed: śloka ātmakasya pariccheda samvalitasya cakra savara mūla tantrasya anuvādaḥ sarva prathama ratna bhadra maradaḥ dharma indrābhyā kṛtaḥ tad anusāra cakra savarasya paramparā traya nimna aṅkitam asti
translated: The Tibetan translation of the root tantra of Cakrasaṃvara in verse form, consisting of 12 chapters, was first made by Ratnabhadra and Mar Do Dharma Indra. Following that, the lineage of Cakrasaṃvara in three lineages is marked below.

analyzed: vajradhara vajrapāṇi brahyaṇa sarahapāda nāgārjuna śabarīpāda luīpāda dhārikapāda gandhapāda maṇḍūka medaka
translated: Vajradhara, Vajrapāṇi, Brahmā, Saraha, Nāgārjuna, Śavaripāda, Luipa, Dhārikapāda, Gandhapāda, Maṇḍūkapāda, Medaka

analyzed: pāda jālandhara pāda guhya pāda vijaya pāda tilopāda nāḍapāda ādayaḥ prathama paramparāyā samāyānti
translated: pāda, Jālandharapāda, Guhyapāda, Vijayapāda, Tilopapāda, Nāḍapāda, and others come in the first lineage.

original: parampareya nepālasya cītherapāditaḥ marapā yāvat tibbate samāgatā /
analyzed: nepālasya cītherapāditaḥ marapā yāvat tibbate samāgatā
translated: The lineage came from Nepal's Chitwan to Marpa in Tibet.
Vajradhara, Vajra Varahi, Luipa, Dengipa, Vajraghantupa, Jalandhara, Krishna, Kusalanatha, Manduka, Medaka,

analyzed: pāda guhya pāda vijaya pāda tilopāda nāḍapāda ādayaḥ dvitīya paramparāyāḥ gaṇyante
translated: Guhya, Vijaya, Tila, Nad, and others are counted in the second lineage.

analyzed: paramparā iya ṅoga mādhyamena samāyātā
translated: The lineage came to Tibet through Ngog.

analyzed: vajradhara vajra vārāhī kṛṣṇa vārāhī kṛṣṇapāda guhyapāda vijayapāda tilopāda nāḍapāda ādibhyaḥ
translated: Vajradhara, Vajra Varahi, Krishna Varahi, Krishna, Guhya, Vijaya, Tila, Nad, and others in the lineage came to Tibet.

original: nīlagranthakāro gosa locāvā mahodayaḥ cakrasavaram ittha svīkarotivajradharaḥ vajrapāṇiḥ sarahaḥ śabarīpādaḥ luīpādaḥ dārikapādaḥ ḍombīpādaḥ vajraghaṇṭāpādaḥ medakapādaḥ jālandharapādaḥ kṛṣṇācāryaḥ vijayapādaḥ tilopādaḥ nāḍapādaḥ śāntipādaḥ maitrīpādaḥ dīpakarastathā tibbatasya mahānanuvādako ratnabhadraśca /
analyzed: nīlagranthakāraḥ gosa locāvā mahodayaḥ svīkaroti vajradharaḥ vajrapāṇiḥ sarahaḥ śabarīpādaḥ luīpādaḥ dārikapādaḥ ḍombīpādaḥ vajraghaṇṭāpādaḥ medakapādaḥ jālandharapādaḥ kṛṣṇācāryaḥ vijayapādaḥ tilopādaḥ nāḍapādaḥ śāntipādaḥ maitrīpādaḥ dīpakaraḥ tathā tibbatasya mahān anuvādakaḥ ratnabhadraḥ ca
translated: The author of the Blue Annals, Gos Lo tsā ba Mahāsukha, accepts the Cakrasaṃvara in this way: Vajradhara, Vajrapāṇi, Saraha, Śavaripa, Luipa, Dārikapa, Ḍombīpa, Vajraghantāpa, Medakpa, Jālandharapa, Kṛṣṇācārya, Vijayapāda, Tilapa, Nāropa, Śāntipāda, Maitrīpāda, and Dīpaṃkara. And the great commentator of Tibet, Ratnabhdra.

original: tadagre tibbatasya dvitīyamarado paramparāyābuddhajñānaḍākinī luīpādaḍeṅgīpādalāvāpādaindrabhūtikacapādaghaṇṭāpādajālandharapādakṛṣṇapādakuśalanatilopādanāḍapādamanakaśrījñānāni nepālasya bhadantastathā tibbatasya marado prabhṛtayaḥ manti /
analyzed: tad agre tibbatasya dvitīya marado nepālasya bhadantaḥ tathā tibbatasya marado prabhṛtayaḥ manti
translated: Before that, the second Mar do of Tibet, in the lineage: Buddhajñāna, Ḍākinī, Luipa, Ḍengipa, Lavapa, Indrabhūti, Ca, Ghaṇṭāpa, Jālandharapa, Kṛṣṇa, Kuśalānanati, Tilapa, Nāropa, Maṇika, Śrījñāna. And the Nepalese Bhadanta, and the Mar do of Tibet and so forth.

analyzed: jñekośe
translated: And in the Jñanakosa, the existence of the Cakrasaṃvara Āgamas is mentioned.

analyzed: prāyas sarvā paramparā tibbate samāgatā
translated: Almost all the lineages have come to Tibet.

analyzed: bhāratīyāḥ sarve siddhāḥ etad tantra anusāra siddhim alabhanta
translated: All the Indian siddhas attained siddhi by following this tantra.

original: ataḥ sādhanāyāḥ anekaparamparāḥ syurityatra nāsti sandehaḥ /
analyzed: atas sādhanāyāḥ aneka paramparāḥ syuḥ iti atra na asti sandehaḥ
translated: Therefore, there are many lineages of practice in this regard, there is no doubt.

analyzed: teṣu luīpāda ghaṇṭāpāda kṛṣṇāpāda ādayaḥ pramukhāḥ santi
translated: Among them, the chief ones are Luipada, Ghantapada, Krishnapada, and others.

analyzed: etad atirikta dārika pāda ḍombī pāda kaniṣṭhaḥ arthāt
translated: Apart from this, there are the practices of Darichapada, Dombipada, Kanistha, Indrabhu, Tilaka, Ajina, Bhadra, Durjaya, Chandrapurva, Digvatila, and Avapada, which are the practices of emptiness meditation.

original: vajrapāṇeḥ uttaravartiāmnāyo balabhadrabrāhyaṇaratnavajrādayo mūlatantropari svatantrarūpeṇa vyākhyānasādhanāprāṇālyoḥ praśastamārga kṛtavantaḥ
analyzed: vajrapāṇeḥ uttara varti āmnāyaḥ balabhadra brāhyaṇa ratnavajra ādayaḥ mūlatantra upari svatantra rūpeṇa vyākhyāna sādhanā prāṇālyoḥ praśasta mārga kṛtavantaḥ
translated: Apart from this, Vajrapani's northern lineage, the practices of Balabhadra Brahmana, Ratnavjra, and others, have created an excellent path for the explanation and practice based on the root tantra.
Apart from this, there is the method of Nagabodhi.

analyzed: kalahasa kumārasya vidhiḥ
translated: There is the method of Kalha Sakumara.

original: sarvadevasamūhānā kṛṣṇavajre dhyānakaraṇasya dharmapādavidhistathā pitṛmātṛdevasamānavarṇe'nyānucaradevānā vibhinnarūpeṇa bhāvanārtha ghuṇḍarīpādavidhirityucyate /
analyzed: sarva deva samūhānā kṛṣṇa vajre dhyāna karaṇasya dharmapāda vidhiḥ tathā vibhinna rūpeṇa bhāvanā artha ghuṇḍarīpāda vidhiḥ iti ucyate
translated: The method of Dharmapada for meditating on Krishnavajra, the collection of all gods, and the method of Ghundaripada for visualizing the gods who have the same color as the father and mother gods in different forms.

analyzed: anye api caḍīpāda nāḍīpāda dhanyapādānāḥ vidhayaḥ
translated: There are also other systems like Chadipada, Nadipada, Dhanipada.

analyzed: etat atiricya vīṇāpāda anantapāda bhadrapāda laḍakapādaka kalapāda jayānanda ādayaḥ
translated: Apart from these, there are systems like Vina pada, Ananta pada, Bhadra pada, Ladaka pada, Kalapada, Jayananda, etc.

analyzed: siddhaiḥ svatantra rūpeṇa pratipāditāḥ
translated: These have been propounded by Siddhas independently.

original: etadatirikta kālacakre vyākṛtā bodhivajrasya paddhatiḥ madhyabhārate tu na /
analyzed: etad atirikta kālacakre vyākṛtā bodhi vajrasya paddhatiḥ madhyabhārate tu na
translated: Apart from this, the system of Bodhivajra was not propagated in Madhyadesha in the Kalachakra.

original: kintu draviḍe asya pūrṇaḥ pracāraḥ prasāraśca jāto'dyāpi labhyate ca /🔽bustonena cakrasavarasyaitādṛśī paramparā svīkṛtāvajradharavajrapāṇisaharanāgārjunaśabarīpādaluīpādadārikapādavajraghaṇṭāpādakukkurīpādajālandharapādakṛṣṇācāryaguhyapādavijayapādatilopādanāḍapādaabhayakīrtivāgīśvaraprajñākuṭatibbatīyamatikīrtiakṣobhyavajrādayaśca
analyzed: kintu draviḍe asya pūrṇaḥ pracāraḥ prasāraḥ ca labhyate ca  bustonena cakra savarasya etādṛśī paramparā svīkṛtā vajradhara vajrapāṇi sahara nāgārjuna śabarīpāda luīpāda dārikapāda vajraghaṇṭāpāda kukkurīpāda jālandhara pāda kṛṣṇa ācārya guhya pāda vijaya pāda tilopāda nāḍapāda abhayakīrti vāgīśvara prajñākuṭa tibbatīya matikīrti akṣobhya vajra ādayaḥ ca
translated: But in Dravida, its full propagation and spread took place and is still found.🔽And Buston accepted such a lineage of the Chakrasaṃvara as Vajradhara, Vajrapāṇi, Sahar, Nāgārjuna, Śabaripada, Lūipada, Dārikapāda, Vajraghantāpada, Kukkurīpāda, Jālandharapāda, Kṛṣṇācārya, Guhyapāda, Vijayapāda, Tilapada, Naḍipada, Abhayakīrti, Vāgīśvara, Prajñākuṭa, Tibetan Mati, Kīrtimati, Akṣobhyavajra, etc.

analyzed: atas cakra savare bahuśas vyākhyāḥ sādhanā paddhatayaḥ ca santi
translated: Therefore, there are many commentaries and sadhana systems on the Chakrasaṃvara.

original: tatra mūlatantrasya bodhisattvacakrapāṇinā uttarārddhavyākhyānāmekasya granthasya racanā vidhāyānuttarayogatantrasya gūdārthatattvāni kālacakrasādhanāpaddhatau sammelya vyākhyā kṛtā /
analyzed: tatra mūla tantrasya bodhisattva cakrapāṇinā uttara arddha vyākhyānām ekasya granthasya racanā vidhāya anuttara yoga tantrasya kālacakra sādhanā paddhatau sammelya vyākhyā kṛtā
translated: There, Bodhisattva Cakrapāṇi composed a text explaining the latter half of the root tantra, and the true meanings of the Anuttara Yoga Tantra were explained in the Kalacakra Sadhana Paddhati, combining them.

original: rājñā indrabhūtinā mūlatantrabhiprāyasya mātṛtantrasya sāmānyapaddhativat sampuṭatantravat
analyzed: rājñā indrabhūtinā mūla tantra abhiprāyasya mātṛ tantrasya sāmānya paddhati vat sampuṭa tantra vat
translated: King Indrabhūti explained the intended meaning of the root tantra in the Mātṛtantra, like the general Paddhati and the Saṃpuṭa Tantra.

analyzed: vyākhyā kṛtā
translated: The explanation was made.

original: ācāryanakṣatracandreṇa yoginītaḥ sākṣādupadeśamupaśrutya mūlatantrīyābhiprāyasyābhidhānottaratantranāmake granthe utpattikramavat vyākhyā kurvatā 'cakrasavarodayasādhanopāyikā amṛtatṛṣita' nāmakasya granthasya racanā kṛtā /
analyzed: ācārya nakṣatracandreṇa yoginītaḥ sākṣāt upadeśam upaśrutya mūla tantrīya abhiprāyasya abhidhāna uttara tantra nāmake granthe utpatti krama vat vyākhyā kurvatā cakra savara udaya sādhana upāyikā amṛtatṛṣita nāmakasya granthasya racanā kṛtā
translated: The Ācārya Nakṣatracandra, having directly received instruction from the Yoginī, explained the intended meaning of the root tantra in the text named Abhidhānottara Tantra, like the order of origination, and composed the text named Cakrasaṃvara Udayasādhanopāyikāmṛtatṛṣit.

analyzed: tad vyākhyā bhavyakīrtinā kṛtā
translated: That explanation was made by Bhavya Kīrti.

original: pañjikā vyākhyā ca miśrīkṛtya punastathāgatarakṣitenaiṣā vyākhyā kṛtā /
analyzed: pañjikā vyākhyā ca miśrīkṛtya punar tathāgata rakṣitena eṣā vyākhyā kṛtā
translated: The commentary was made by Tathāgatarañjit by mixing the Pañjikā and the commentary.

analyzed: ete sarve granthāḥ cakrasavara mātṛtantra paddhati vat vyākhyānti
translated: All these texts explain the Cakrasaṃvara like the Mātṛtantra Paddhati.

original: lāvāpāda devaguptasumati kīrtyādibhirapi paramparāyāmasyā cakrasavarasya vyākhyāḥ vihitāḥ /
analyzed: devagupta sumati kīrti ādibhiḥ api paramparāyām asya cakra savarasya vyākhyāḥ vihitāḥ
translated: Lavapa, Devagupta, Sumati, Kirti, and others also composed commentaries on this Cakrasamvara in succession.

analyzed: etat atiricya tibbatī bhāṣāyām anūdita cakrasavarasya śabda artha prakāśaḥ alābhacandrasya ratna gaṇanā nāma pañjikā
translated: Apart from this, there is a commentary on the Cakrasamvara translated into Tibetan language, called Ratnaganana by Alahabhadra.

analyzed: śāśvata vajrasya pramukhāḥ santi
translated: Shavtavajra's Svaravritti and others are prominent.

original: ittha cakrasavarasyānekaparamparā āmnāyānā sādhanāpaddhatayaśca pracalitā āsan /
analyzed: cakra savarasya aneka paramparā sādhanā paddhatayaḥ ca pracalitāḥ āsan
translated: Thus, there were many lineages and methods of practice of the Cakrasamvara.

original: prāyaśaḥ siddhā api cakrasavarasya sādhanayaiva siddhi labdhavantaḥ /
analyzed: prāyaśas siddhāḥ api cakra savarasya sādhanayā eva siddhi labdhavantaḥ
translated: Most of them attained perfection only through the practice of the Cakrasamvara.

original: mahāmāyā mahāmāyātantrasya paramparā bhāratavarṣe ācāryavinayadattaratnākaraśāntipādādibhyo'tiriktā anyā apyanekā mahāmāyātantrasya paramparā āsan /
analyzed: mahāmāyā mahāmāyā tantrasya paramparā bhārata varṣe ācārya vinayadatta ratnākara śāntipāda ādibhyaḥ utiriktā anyāḥ api anekāḥ mahāmāyā tantrasya paramparāḥ āsan
translated: In India, apart from Acharya Vinayadattaratnakarashantipada and others, there were many other lineages of the Mahamaya Tantra.

original: tibbate mahāmāyātantrasya sarvaprathama pracāraḥ prasāraśca nīlagranthakāreṇa gosalomahodayena tathā dīpaṅkaraśrījñānena bhoṭabhāṣāyāmanūdya
analyzed: tibbate mahāmāyā tantrasya sarva prathama pracāraḥ prasāraḥ ca nīla granthakāreṇa gosalaḥ mahodayena tathā dīpaṅkara śrī jñānena bhoṭa bhāṣāyām anūdya
translated: In Tibet, the first propagation and spread of the Mahamaya Tantra was done by Neelagranthakara Goshalamohidaya and Dipankara Shrijnana by translating it into the Tibetan language and

original: kintu samprati eteṣā paramparā tatra nopalabhyate /
analyzed: kintu samprati eteṣā paramparā tatra na upalabhyate
translated: But at present, their lineage is not found there.

original: śāntibhadrādīnā paramparāpi bhārate vidyamānā āsīt yasyāstibbatīyena mahatānuvādakena marapāmahodayena dharmapatinā
analyzed: śāntibhadra ādīnā paramparā api bhārate vidyamānā āsīt yasyāḥ tibbatīyena mahatā anuvādakena marapā mahodayena dharmapatinā
translated: The lineage of Shantibhadra and others was also present in India, which was propagated and spread by the great Tibetan translator Marpa Lodro Gyaltsen, the Dharma Lord,

analyzed: śravaṇa paramparayā pracāraḥ prasāraḥ ca kṛtaḥ
translated: through the lineage of hearing.

analyzed: mahāmāyāyāḥ paramparā
translated: The lineage of the Great Maya according to the Buston tradition is as follows: Vajradhara, Dakini, Kukkuripa, Saraha, Vajradobhi, Heruka,

analyzed: tilopāda nāḍapāda jñāna bhadra tibbatīya mahānuvādaka dharmamati ādayaḥ ca
translated: Tilopa, Naropa, Jnanabhadra, the great Tibetan translator Dharmamati, and others.

original: mahāmāyātantrīyaṭīkāsu durjayacandrasya pañjikā māyāvatī ratnākaraśāntipādasya guṇavatī ṭīkā kṛṣṇasamayavajrasya mahāmāyātantrasmṛtivṛtti alaṅkārapādasya pañjikā dharmamateḥ mahāmāyāniṣpannakramādayoḥ anaṅgavajraratnavajrādīnāmaneke sādhanopāyikādayo granthāḥ pramukhāḥ santi /
analyzed: mahāmāyātantrīya ṭīkāsu durjayacandrasya pañjikā māyāvatī ratnākara śānti pādasya guṇavatī ṭīkā kṛṣṇa samaya vajrasya mahāmāyātantra smṛti vṛtti alaṅkāra pādasya pañjikā dharmamateḥ mahāmāyā niṣpanna krama ādayoḥ anaṅga vajra ratna vajra ādīnām aneke sādhana upāyika ādayaḥ granthāḥ pramukhāḥ santi
translated: Among the commentaries on the Great Maya Tantra, there are many important texts such as the commentary on the Great Maya Tantra by Durjayachandra, the commentary Maya-vati, the commentary Gunavati by Ratnakara-shantipada, the commentary on the Great Maya Tantra Smriti by Krishna-samaya-vajra, the commentary on the Great Maya Tantra by Alamkara-pada, the commentary on the Great Maya Tantra by Dharmamati, the commentaries on the stages of accomplishment of the Great Maya Tantra by Ananga-vajra, Ratnavajra, and others, and many sadhana manuals and other texts.

analyzed: catuṣpīṭhasya paramparā catuṣpīṭhasya bhārata varṣena eka paramparāḥ āsan
translated: The lineage of the Catuspīṭha in India had many lineages in the land of Bhārata.

original: catuṣpīṭhamūlatantrīyavyākhyāśritā sthāpitā''ryadevaparamparā tathā catuṣpīṭhasagrahādhāritā bhavabhadraparamparā''su mukhyā āsan /
analyzed: catuṣpīṭha mūla tantrīya vyākhyā āśritā sthāpitā ārya deva paramparā tathā catuṣpīṭha sagraha ādhāritāḥ bhava bhadra paramparāsu mukhyāḥ āsan
translated: The lineage of Āryadeva based on the commentary on the root tantra of the Catuspīṭha, and the lineage of Bhava-bhadra based on the collection of the Catuspīṭha, were the main ones.

analyzed: imāḥ tibbatīya bhāṣāyām anūdya prācāryanta
translated: These were translated into Tibetan by the venerable Gayadhara, Doga, and Bhima, and taught.

original: tatra narāsthidhāriṇī ḍākinītaḥ abhiṣekopadeśau prāpya marapādharmamatinā tasyāḥ paramparāyāḥ pracāraḥ prasāraśca kṛtaḥ /🔽bustonena catuṣpīṭhasya paramparettha svīkṛtāvajradharavajraḍākinī nāgārjunaāryadevaprajñābhadra nāḍapādatibbatīyānuvādakadharmamatyādiḥ
analyzed: tatra nara asthi dhāriṇī ḍākinītaḥ abhiṣeka upadeśau prāpya marapā dharma matinā tasyāḥ paramparāyāḥ pracāraḥ prasāraḥ ca kṛtaḥ  catuṣpīṭhasya svīkṛtā a vajradhara vajra ḍākinī nāgārjuna ārya deva prajñābhadra nāḍapāda tibbatīya anuvādaka dharma mati ādiḥ
translated: There, having received the consecration and instructions from the ḍākinī holding human bones, the lineage of Marpa-dharmamati was propagated and spread.🔽And the lineage of the Catuspīṭha was accepted by Buston, from Vajradhara-vajra-ḍākinī, Nāgārjuna, Āryadeva, Prajñābhadra, Nāḍapāda, the Tibetan translator Dharmamati, and so on.

original: catuṣpīṭhasya ṭīkāsubhavadrasya śrīcatuṣpīṭhatantrarājasmṝtinibandhaḥ kuśalavarmaṇaścatuṣpīṭhaṭīkā āryadevasya gambhīrārthanirdeśaḥ ekadrumapañjikā /
analyzed: catuṣpīṭhasya ṭīkā subhavadrasya śrī catuṣpīṭha tantrarāja smṝti nibandhaḥ kuśalavarmaṇaḥ catuṣpīṭha ṭīkā āryadevasya gambhīra artha nirdeśaḥ ekadrumapañjikā
translated: In the commentaries on the Catuspīṭha, there is Śrī-catuspīṭha-tantra-rāja-smṛti-nibandha by Subhadra, Catuspīṭha-ṭīkā by Kuśala-varman, Gambhīra-artha-nirdeśa by Āryadeva, and Ekadruma-pañjikā.
The means of accomplishment of the Yoga Tantra of the Four Seats.
The Sadhana of the Vajracatuḥpīṭha composed by Jagadānanda, Jīvabhadra, and others are considered primary.

original: buddhakapālasya paramparā buddhakapālatantrasya sarahapādābhyākarayoḥ paramparādvaya tibbate samāgatam /
analyzed: buddha kapālasya paramparā buddha kapāla tantrasya sa rahapāda abhyākarayoḥ samāgatam
translated: The lineage of Buddhakapāla's tantra, along with the two lineages of Sarahapāda, has come to Tibet.

analyzed: buddhakapāla tantre sarahapādasya pañjikā ajñānavatī
translated: In the Buddhakapāla Tantra, there is Jñānavatī, the commentary on Sarahapāda's Pada.

original: sādhanopāyikā abhayākaraguptasyābhayapaddhati nāmakagranthamatiricya padyavajrasya tattvacandrikā nāmikā pañjikā'pi tibbatībhāṣānuvādasavalitopalabhyate
analyzed: sādhana upāyikā abhayākaraguptasya abhaya paddhati nāmaka grantham atiricya padya vajrasya tattvacandrikā nāmikā pañjikā api tibbatī bhāṣā anuvāda savalitā upalabhyate
translated: Apart from Abhayākaragupta's work named Abhayapaddhati, the commentary named Tattvacandrikā by Padavajra is also found in the Tibetan translation along with the Sadhanopāyikā.

original: kālacakrasya śambhalaparamparā bhagavān buddhaḥ śambhalasya rājñe sucandrāya kālacakrasyopadeśa kṛtavān /
analyzed: kālacakrasya śambhala paramparā bhagavān buddhaḥ śambhalasya rājñe sucandrāya kālacakrasya upadeśa kṛtavān
translated: The lineage of Śambhala for the Kālacakra: The Blessed Buddha gave the teaching of the Kālacakra to King Sucandra of Śambhala.

original: anenaiva kālacakrīyamūlatantra sagṛhyānuśasā nāmaka grantha chandasi ślokeṣḥu viracayya śambhaladeśe'sya pracāraḥ prasāraśca kṛtaḥ
analyzed: anena eva kālacakrīya mūlatantra sagṛhyānuśasā nāmaka grantha chandasi viracayya pracāraḥ prasāraḥ ca kṛtaḥ
translated: By him alone, having taken the root tantra of the Kālacakra along with the Anuśāsana named the Śrīparamādya, having composed it in the form of verses in the form of metrical ślokas, its propagation and spread was done in the land of Śambhala.

original: bhagavataḥ parinirvāṇasya varṣatrayānantarameva kālacakramahāmaṇḍala nirmāya rājā sucandraḥ parinirvāṇa prāptavān /
analyzed: bhagavataḥ parinirvāṇasya varṣa traya anantaram eva kālacakra mahā maṇḍala nirmāya rājā sucandraḥ parinirvāṇa prāptavān
translated: Three years after the parinirvāṇa of the Blessed One, King Sucandra created the Kālacakra Mahāmaṇḍala and attained parinirvāṇa.

original: paścādasya paramparāyā devendratejasvicandradattadevendravirūpadevendravān nāmakāḥ ṣaḍ dharmarājāḥ samāgatāḥ /
analyzed: paścāt asya paramparāyāḥ deva indra tejasvi candradatta devendra virūpadeva indravān nāmakāḥ ṣaṭ dharma rājāḥ samāgatāḥ
translated: After him, six Dharma kings named Devendra, Tejasvin, Candradatta, Devendravirūpa, and Devendravan came in succession.

analyzed: ebhiḥ sarvaiḥ mūlatantrasya vyākhyā kṛtā
translated: All of them composed commentaries on the root tantra.

original: tataḥ kulikavaśīyeṣu rājasu kecana samāgatāḥ kecana samāgantāra āsan /
analyzed: tatas kulika vaśīyeṣu rājasu kecana samāgatāḥ kecana samāgantāraḥ āsan
translated: Then, among the kings of the Kulīya dynasty, some assembled and some were about to assemble.

original: teṣu sarvaprathama mañjughoṣakīrtinā'pi kālacakrīyamūlatantrasyaiva pracāraḥ kṛtaḥ yathā sūryarathādibhirṛṣimunibhirnivedane kṛte bṛhanmūlakālacakratantrasya sagrahaḥ sragdharācchandasi ślokeṣu kṛtastathā svīyavaśīyena kulikapuṇḍarīkena
analyzed: teṣu mañjughoṣa kīrtinā api kālacakrīya mūla tantrasya eva pracāraḥ kṛtaḥ yathā sūryaratha ādibhiḥ ṛṣi munibhiḥ nivedane kṛte bṛhat mūla kālacakra tantrasya sa grahaḥ sragdharā chandasi ślokeṣu kṛtaḥ tathā svīya vaśīyena kulika puṇḍarīkena  /
translated: Among them, Mañjughoṣakīrti first propagated the Kālacakra Root Tantra, just as the sages and seers beginning with Sūryaratha composed the Kālacakra Root Tantra in the Sragdharā meter in twelve thousand verses, and his own Kulīya-puṇḍarīka composed a commentary on it in the same meter.

analyzed: dvādaśa sāhasrikā vimalaprabhā vyākhyā racitā
translated: The twelve thousand verse Vimalaprabhā commentary was composed by him.

analyzed: kramaśas bhadra vijaya miśra bhadra raktapāṇi viṣṇugupta sūryakīrti ādayaḥ rājānaḥ bhavan
translated: After Pundarika, the kings were Bhadravijaya, Mishra-Bhadra, Raktapāṇi, Viṣṇugupta, Sūryakīrti, and others.

original: aṣṭamasya sudivyanāmakasya rājñaḥ samaye mlecchadharmasya prādurbhāvo jāta ityuktam /
analyzed: aṣṭamasya sudivya nāmakasya rājñaḥ samaye mleccha dharmasya prādurbhāvaḥ jātaḥ iti uktam
translated: It is said that in the time of the eighth king named Sudivya, the Mleccha religion appeared.

analyzed: asya sa vistara vyākhyā kālacakrasya vimalaprabhā ṭīkāyām upalabhyate
translated: A detailed explanation of this Kālacakra is found in the commentary Vimalaprabhā.

analyzed: kulika rājñā paramparā nimna aṅkitā vidyate sāgaravijayaḥ
translated: After Sudivya, there is a lineage of kings named Kulika, listed below: Sāgaravijaya,

analyzed: sūryaḥ
translated: Sūrya,

analyzed: virūpaḥ
translated: Virūpa,
Candraprabha,

analyzed: anantaḥ bhūmipālaḥ
translated: Ananta, Bhūmipāla,

analyzed: śrī pālaḥ siha
translated: Śrīpāla, Siṃha,

analyzed: vikrāntaḥ mahā balaḥ anirūddhaḥ narasihaḥ
translated: Vikrānta, Mahābala, Aniruddha, Narasiṃha,
Maheśvara,

analyzed: anantaḥ vijayaḥ ca antimaḥ krodhacakrī ca iti āgāmiṣyanti
translated: and Ananta Vijaya, the last one being Krodhacakrin. They will come.

analyzed: sarve varṣa yāvat śāsana kariṣyanti
translated: All of them will rule for a certain number of years.

original: kālacakramatānusāra bhoṭadeśīyaviduṣā matamasti yad rājñaḥ sudivyasya samaye mlecchadharmaḥ āvirbhaviṣyati kramaśaḥ /
analyzed: kālacakra mata anusāra bhoṭa deśīya viduṣā matam asti yat rājñaḥ su divyasya samaye mleccha dharmaḥ āvirbhaviṣyati kramaśas
translated: According to the Kālacakra, there is an opinion among the scholars of Tibet that the Mleccha religion will gradually appear in the time of King Sudivya.

original: antimaḥ krodhacakrī mlecchān samūla vināśya saddharmasya pracāra kariṣyati tathā punaḥ kṛtayugaḥ samāgamiṣyati /
analyzed: antimaḥ krodha cakrī mlecchān sa mūla vināśya saddharmasya pracāra kariṣyati tathā punar kṛta yugaḥ samāgamiṣyati
translated: The last one, Krodhacakrin, will completely destroy the Mlecchas and will spread the true Dharma. Then again, the Kṛta age will come.

original: jyotiṣā cāryāṇā matānusāra buddhasya parinirvāṇam adyato varṣebhyaḥ pūrvameva jātamiti /
analyzed: jyotiṣā ca āryāṇā mata anusāra buddhasya parinirvāṇam adyatas varṣebhyaḥ pūrvam eva jātam iti
translated: According to the Jyotisa of the Āryas, the Buddha's parinirvāṇa occurred many years ago.

original: sucandreṇa mūlatantrasya sagrahaḥ varṣapūrvameva kṛto'sya parinirvāṇa varṣapūrvameva jātam /🔽kulikamañjukīrtinā sagrahatantrasya punaḥ sakṣepaḥ varṣapūrvameva kṛtastathā mlecchānā samayaḥ varṣapūrvamevāsīt /
analyzed: sucandreṇa mūla tantrasya sagrahaḥ varṣa pūrvam eva kṛtaḥ usya parinirvāṇa varṣa pūrvam eva jātam  kulika mañjukīrtinā sagraha tantrasya punar sakṣepaḥ varṣa pūrvam eva kṛtaḥ tathā samayaḥ varṣa pūrvam eva āsīt
translated: Sucira, before his parinirvāṇa, composed the root tantra with its commentary many years ago.🔽Kulīka Mañjukeertin, before his parinirvāṇa, composed the concise tantra with its commentary many years ago. Thus, the time of the Mlecchas was many years ago.

original: varṣamādhārīkṛtya buddhasya parinirvāṇa ī pūrvamabhūt tathā mlecchānā prādurbhāvakālaḥ khiṣṭavarṣasamīpe bhavati antimaḥ kulikarājaḥ varṣasamīpa āgamiṣyati /
analyzed: varṣam ādhārīkṛtya buddhasya parinirvāṇe pūrvam abhūt tathā mlecchānā prādurbhāva kālaḥ khiṣṭa varṣa samīpe bhavati antimaḥ kulika rājaḥ varṣa samīpe āgamiṣyati
translated: Taking the year as the basis, the Buddha's parinirvāṇa occurred many years ago. Thus, the time of the appearance of the Mlecchas is near the end of the Kali Yuga. The last Kulīka king will come near the end of the Kali Yuga.

original: kālacakrasya āryadeśīyaparamparā bustonānusāra kālacakrasyāryāvarte pracāraḥ rājatrayasya śāsanakāle śambhaladeśata āmantritena cilupaṇḍitena kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: kālacakrasya ārya deśīya paramparā bustona anusāra kālacakrasya āryāvarte pracāraḥ rāja trayasya śāsana kāle śambhala deśataḥ āmantritena cilu paṇḍitena kṛtaḥ
translated: The spread of the Kālacakra in the noble land was done by the invited scholar Cilupa from the country of Śambhala during the reign of the three kings.

original: nīlagranthe goelocāvā mahodayenokta yat sāmānyataḥ vajrayānasya janasāmānye
analyzed: nīlagranthe mahodayena ukta yat sāmānyatas vajra yānasya jana sāmānye
translated: It is said in the Blue Annals by Gö Lotsāwa that in general, the spread and propagation of the Vajrayāna

original: pracāraḥ prasāraśca pūrvadigvāsino rājñaḥ prakāśacandrasya samaye jātaḥ /
analyzed: pracāraḥ prasāraḥ ca pūrva diś vāsinaḥ rājñaḥ prakāśacandrasya samaye jātaḥ
translated: among ordinary people took place during the time of King Pṛthivīmalla of Nepal.

analyzed: anena tathāgata loka sagraha ādi yoga tantrāṇā vyākhyā kṛtā
translated: By him, the Tantra of the Union of the Tathāgata and the World was explained.

original: tadanantaram ācāryanāgārjunena tacchiṣyaiśca guhyasamājapitṛtantrādīnā dakṣiṇabhārate vyākhyāna kṛtam /
analyzed: tad anantaram ācārya nāgārjunena tad śiṣyaiḥ ca guhya samāja pitṛ tantra ādīnām dakṣiṇa bhārate vyākhyāna kṛtam
translated: After that, by Ācārya Nāgārjuna and his disciples, the Guhyasamāja Piti Tantra and others were explained in South India.

analyzed: tad anantara lāvā pādena uttara diśi aoḍiyāna āditaḥ
translated: After that, by Lavapa, the Yoginī Mātri Tantra

analyzed: āmantrya madhyadeśe pracāraḥ prasāraḥ ca kṛtaḥ
translated: was spread and propagated in the north from Oddiyāna and so on, and invited to the central country.

original: tataḥ śambhalataḥ kālacakramānīya cilupādādibhirasya pracāraḥ kṛtaḥ /
