translated: Recollection is nourished by the limb of meditation, which is the cultivated form of emptiness through the door of the limb of withdrawal.

original: prāṇāyāmena nāḍīvāyutilakāni niyantrya dhāraṇayā tilaka madhyamāyā sthirīkriyate /🔽pratyāhāradhyānābhyā dṛdīkṛta śūnyarūpamākāśavad tadanusmṛtikaraṇameva anusmṛtyākhya yogāṅgamāste /
analyzed: prāṇāyāmena nāḍī vāyu tilakāni niyantrya dhāraṇayā tilaka madhyamāyā sthirīkriyate  pratyāhāra dhyānābhyā śūnya rūpam ākāśa vat tad anusmṛti karaṇam eva yoga aṅgam āste
translated: By means of breath control, the tilings in the form of the breath in the channels are restrained, and by means of retention, it is stabilized in the middle of the forehead.🔽The form of emptiness made firm by withdrawal and meditation, like space, is just the performance of that recollection, which is the limb of yoga called recollection.

original: guhyasamājottaratantre vibhāvya yadanusmṛtyā tadākāra tu sasmaret /
analyzed: guhya samāja uttara tantre vibhāvya yad anusmṛtyā tad ākāra tu sasmaret
translated: In the Guhyasamaja Uttaratantra, it is said: Having visualized it by means of recollection, then one should remember that form.

analyzed: anusmṛtiḥ iya jñeyā pratibhāsaḥ utra jāyate
translated: This should be known as recollection, and the appearance arises here.

original: sekoddeśaṭīkāyāmapi matamida suspaṣṭīkṛtam pratyāhāradhyānābhyā sthirīkṛtatridhātupratibhāsātmakasavṛtisatyasya sasfaraṇamarthāt tasya nikhilākāśe vyāptividhānamevānusmṛtiḥ /
analyzed: seka uddeśa ṭīkāyām api su spaṣṭīkṛtam pratyāhāra dhyānābhyā sthirīkṛta tri dhātu pratibhāsa ātmaka sa vṛti satyasya sa sfaraṇam arthāt tasya nikhila ākāśe vyāpti vidhānam eva anusmṛtiḥ
translated: And in the Sekoddesatika, this view is made very clear: The filling of the entire space of the three realms, which is the nature of the appearance of the covered truth, made firm by withdrawal and meditation, is indeed the pervasion of that throughout the entire space, which is recollection.

original: bustonaḥ anusmṛtilakṣaṇa suspaṣṭayan akathayat dhāraṇāṅgasya sādhanābalena nābhikṣetre caṇḍālī prajvālya caṇḍālīsvabhāve pratibimbasadṛśanirvikalpatridhātukātmakasveṣṭadevasya ābhāsasthitirevānusmṛtiḥ /
analyzed: bustonaḥ anusmṛti lakṣaṇa suspaṣṭayan akathayat dhāraṇā aṅgasya sādhanā balena nābhi kṣetre caṇḍālī prajvālya caṇḍālī svabhāve pratibimba sadṛśa nirvikalpa tri dhātuka ātmaka sva iṣṭadevasya ābhāsa sthitiḥ eva anusmṛtiḥ
translated: Buston, clarifying the definition of recollection, said that by the power of the means of the part of concentration, the appearance of one's own desired deity, which is of the nature of the three realms without conceptualization, like a reflection, is established in the field of the navel, which is the recollection.

original: kālcakratantre cāpi caṇḍālyālokana yad bhavati khalu tanau cāmbare'nusmṛtiḥ syāt /
analyzed: kālcakra tantre ca api yat bhavati khalu tanau syāt
translated: And in the Kālacakra Tantra also, what occurs on the body and in the sky is indeed the recollection of the vision of the Caṇḍālī.

analyzed: sādhakasya indriyāṇām mṛdu madhyama uttama bhedena bheda trayam
translated: The practitioner has three divisions based on the division of the faculties into weak, medium, and strong.

original: sumeroḥ kaṇasadṛśānantamahāmudrābhiḥ sāka samāhitatvavidhāyakaḥ uttamaḥ jñānātmakamahāmudrayā saha madhyamaḥ karmamahāmudrayā saha samāhitaḥ sādhakaśca mṛdurasti /
analyzed: sumeroḥ kaṇa sadṛśa ananta mahāmudrābhiḥ sāka samāhita tva vidhāyakaḥ uttamaḥ jñāna ātmaka mahāmudrayā saha madhyamaḥ karma mahāmudrayā saha samāhitaḥ sādhakaḥ ca mṛduḥ asti
translated: The superior one is the one who is concentrated with the infinite great mudrās resembling particles of Mount Meru; the medium one is the one who is concentrated with the knowledge-based great mudrā; and the weak practitioner is the one who is concentrated with the karma-based great mudrā.

analyzed: kālacakre pi etat mṛdu ādi bhedaiḥ trividham api bhavet sādhana viśvabhartuḥ
translated: And in the Kālacakra also, this practice of the lord of the universe would be threefold based on these weak and other divisions.

analyzed: tisraḥ mudrāḥ tri mātrāḥ trividha gati vaśāt karma sakalpa divyāḥ
translated: The three mudrās, the three measures, are the divine ones of action based on the three types of movements.

original: sādhanāsthala kālacakre ittha suspaṣṭīkṛtam etā mudrāścatasro'kṣarasukhafaladā yoginā bhāvanīyāḥ /
analyzed: sādhanā sthala kālacakre ittha su spaṣṭīkṛtam etāḥ mudrāḥ catasraḥ ukṣara sukha fala dāḥ yoginā bhāvanīyāḥ
translated: In the Wheel of Time, these four mudras are clearly explained in this way. They should be cultivated by the yogi for the blissful fruit of the syllables.

analyzed: sarvasmin sarvakāla surata rati gataiḥ loka mārgaḥ prayuktaḥ
translated: In all, at all times, the worldly path is employed by those who have attained the delightful bliss.

analyzed: grāma araṇya śmaśāne śuci śuci nilaye veśma devālaye ca
translated: In the village, forest, charnel ground, in the abode of the pure and impure, in the house and temple,

analyzed: varṇa a varṇa abhicāraiḥ tanu bala sukha daiḥ anna pāna ādi bhogaiḥ
translated: With the enjoyments of food, drink, and so forth, which bestow the body, strength, and happiness of the mantra and non-mantra practices.

analyzed: sāmānyatas yathā pratyāhāra aṅgena kāya vajra sādhanā vidhīyate
translated: In general, as taught in the limbs of the pratyahara, the practice of the body vajra is performed.

analyzed: dhyāna aṅgena tatra dṛdatā prāpyate
translated: By the limb of meditation, firmness is attained there.

original: prāṇāyāmena ca vāyu niyantrya vāgvajrasādhanā kriyate dhāraṇayā ca tatra dārdya sampādyate tathaivānusmṛtyā cittavajraḥ sādhyate samādhinā ca tad dārdya prāpya paramapadamavāpyate /
analyzed: prāṇāyāmena ca vāyu niyantrya vāc vajra sādhanā kriyate dhāraṇayā ca tatra dārdya sampādyate tathā eva anusmṛtyā citta vajraḥ sādhyate samādhinā ca tat dārdya prāpya parama padam avāpyate
translated: And by the breath control, having controlled the breath, the practice of the speech vajra is done. By the retention, firmness is accomplished there. In the same way, the mind vajra is accomplished by the recollection. And by the samadhi, having attained firmness there, the supreme state is attained.

original: kālacakre pitṛtantramātṛtantrābhyā bhinna uṣṇīṣakaṇṭhahṛdayeṣu nāḍīcakre ca pṛthak pṛthak caturbindūnāmastitvamurarīkṛtam /
analyzed: kālacakre pitṛ tantra mātṛ tantrābhyā bhinne uṣṇīṣa kaṇṭha hṛdayeṣu nāḍī cakre ca pṛthak pṛthak catur bindūnām astitvam urarīkṛtam
translated: In the Wheel of Time, it is accepted that the four drops exist separately in the ushnisha, throat, heart, and in the wheel of the nadis, different from the father tantra and mother tantra.

original: ete bindavaḥ jāgradādicaturavasthāsu vāyunā spanditāḥ santaḥ nānābhramān janayanti /🔽yathā jāgradavasthāyā ūrdhvabhāgīyāḥ sarvavāyavaḥ uṣṇīṣacakre /
analyzed: ete bindavaḥ jāgrat ādi catur avasthāsu vāyunā spanditāḥ santaḥ nānā bhramān janayanti  yathā jāgrat avasthāyāḥ ūrdhva bhāgīyāḥ sarva vāyavaḥ uṣṇīṣa cakre
translated: These drops, when vibrated by the air in the four states of waking, etc., produce various illusions.🔽In the waking state, all the upward-moving airs are grasped in the crown cakra,

analyzed: adhobhāgīyāḥ sarva vāyavaḥ ca nābhi cakre sagṛhyante
translated: and all the downward-moving airs in the navel cakra.

analyzed: vibhinna ābhāsa mātra bhrānti ābhāsa ca utpādayanti
translated: They produce the illusion of diverse appearances through the mere illusion of appearance.

original: svapnāvasthāyāmapi ūrdhvavāyavaḥ kaṇṭhacakre adhobhāgīyāśca guhyendriye sagṛhītāḥ śabdamātra vāgbhrānti cotpādayanti /🔽suṣuptau ūrdhvabhāgīyāḥ sarvavāyavaḥ hṛdayacakre adhobhāgīyāśca maṇicakre ekatrībhūya nirvikalpā asfuṭāḥ santo bhrāntimutpādayanti /
analyzed: svapna avasthāyām api ūrdhva vāyavaḥ kaṇṭha cakre adhobhāgīyāḥ ca guhya indriye sa gṛhītāḥ śabda mātra vāc bhrānti ca utpādayanti  suṣuptau ūrdhva bhāgīyāḥ sarva vāyavaḥ hṛdaya cakre adhobhāgīyāḥ ca maṇi cakre ekatrībhūya nirvikalpāḥ asfuṭāḥ santaḥ bhrāntim utpādayanti
translated: In the dream state as well, the upward-moving airs are grasped in the throat cakra, and the downward-moving airs in the genital organ, producing the illusion of mere sound and speech.🔽In deep sleep, all the upward-moving airs in the heart cakra and the downward-moving airs in the jewel cakra unite together, becoming non-conceptual and indistinct, producing illusion.

original: purūṣastriyoḥ samāpatyavasthāyām ūrdhvabhāgīyāḥ sarvavāyavo nābhicakre adhovāyavaśca guhyendriyāgrabhāge sagṛhītāḥ sukhānubhūti srāva cotpādayanti
analyzed: purūṣa striyoḥ samā pati avasthāyām ūrdhvabhāgīyāḥ sarva vāyavaḥ nābhi cakre adhovāyavaḥ ca guhya indriya agra bhāge sa gṛhītāḥ sukha anubhūti srāva ca utpādayanti
translated: In the state of union of male and female, all the upward-moving airs in the navel cakra and the downward-moving airs at the tip of the genital organ are grasped, producing the experience of pleasure and emission.

original: etatpariśuddhyaivābhāsamātra śabdamātra nirvikalpamātra sukhānubhūtīnā vistāreṇa kramaśaḥ kāyavākcittāni jñānavajraśca prāpyante /
analyzed: etad pariśuddhyā eva ābhāsa mātra śabda mātra nirvikalpa mātra sukha anubhūtīnām vistāreṇa kramaśas kāya vāc cittāni jñāna vajraḥ ca prāpyante
translated: By this purification alone, the mere appearances, mere sounds, mere non-conceptual experiences, and mere bliss are gradually expanded, and the body, speech, mind, and wisdom vajras are attained.

original: anusmṛsādhanā karmamudrājñānamudrāmuhāmudrābhiḥ saha samāhitatva vidhāya caṇḍālīyogenānuṣṭhīyate /
analyzed: karma mudrā jñāna mudrā muhā mudrābhiḥ saha caṇḍālī yogena anuṣṭhīyate
translated: It is practiced with the recollection of the accomplishment, the karma mudra, the jnana mudra, and the samaya mudra, by being absorbed, and by the practice of the chandali yoga.

original: kālacakre vātaiḥ saghaṭṭamānaistaḍidanalaśikhā drāvayenmūrdhni cakra yo yo bindurdruto'smād galahṛdayagato nābhiguhye nirūddhaḥ /
analyzed: kālacakre vātaiḥ sa ghaṭṭamānaiḥ taḍit anala śikhāḥ drāvayet mūrdhni cakra yaḥ yaḥ binduḥ drutaḥ usmāt galahṛdaya gataḥ nābhi guhye nirūddhaḥ
translated: In the wheel of time, the cakra on the head is melted by the winds colliding, with the flames of lightning and fire. The bindu that is melted from that descends to the throat and heart, and is held in the navel and genitals.

original: bindoḥ spandadrava yat kuliśamaṇigata sanirūddha dhvajāgre prajñājñānakṣaṇa tadyadi dadati sukha bindumālācyutena //
analyzed: bindoḥ spanda drava yat kuliśa maṇi gata sa nirūddha dhvaja agre prajñā jñāna kṣaṇa tat yadi dadati sukha bindu mālā cyutena
translated: The trembling and flowing of the bindu, which is like the vajra jewel, held at the tip of the flag, if one gives the moment of wisdom and knowledge, with the bliss that falls from the garland of bindus.

analyzed: vāyoḥ madhyamā nāḍyā praveśena caṇḍālī prajvalati
translated: The chandali blazes by the inhalation through the madhyama nadi in the middle of the two winds.

original: trividhaḥ sādhakaḥ svasāmarthyānusāreṇa mudrayā sārdha samāhito bhavati /
analyzed: trividhaḥ sādhakaḥ sva sāmarthya anusāreṇa mudrayā sārdha samāhitaḥ bhavati
translated: The practitioner of three kinds becomes absorbed with the mudra according to his own ability.

original: pratyāhāradhyānābhyā bhāviteṣṭadevānusmṛti kurvāṇaḥ tanmahāsukhādabhinnatā sthāpayitvā dhyāna kurūte /
analyzed: pratyāhāra dhyānābhyā bhāvita iṣṭadeva anusmṛti kurvāṇaḥ sthāpayitvā dhyāna kurūte
translated: Having cultivated the desired deity through the practice of pratyahara and dhyana, he performs the recollection of the deity, establishing himself as inseparable from that great bliss, and performs the dhyana.

original: cakracatuṣṭaye yadā kramaśaḥ tilakam avatiṣṭhate tadā ānandaparamānandaviramānandasahajānandākṣarasukhaprāptirbhavati /
analyzed: cakra catuṣṭaye yadā kramaśas tilakam avatiṣṭhate tadā ānanda paramānanda viramānanda sahajānanda akṣara sukha prāptiḥ bhavati
translated: When the tilaka is present in the four cakras in sequence, then the attainment of the bliss of the imperishable bliss of bliss, supreme bliss, separation bliss, and innate bliss occurs.

analyzed: trividhena sādhakena sva kṣamatā anurūpam akṣara sukha prāptiḥ eva anusmṛti sādhanā vidhiḥ ūcyate
translated: The method of recollecting the practice of attaining the bliss of the imperishable is stated to be in accordance with the capacity of the practitioner of three types.

original: uttamaḥ sādhakaḥ svaprajñaptidhātukātmakamahāmudrayā sāka samāhitaḥ san anusmṛti bhāvayati /
analyzed: uttamaḥ sādhakaḥ sva prajñapti dhātuka ātmaka mahāmudrayā sāka samāhitaḥ san anusmṛti bhāvayati
translated: The best practitioner, being concentrated together with the mahāmudrā consisting of the element of his own wisdom, cultivates recollection.

original: kālacakre'pyuktam na dhyāna mantrajāpaḥ karaṇamapi mahāmaṇḍalānyāsanāni /
analyzed: kālacakre pi uktam na dhyāna mantra jāpaḥ karaṇam api mahā maṇḍalāni āsanāni
translated: It is said in the Kālacakra cycle: Meditation, mantra recitation, and even the performance of the great maṇḍala rituals,

original: homo mantrapratiṣṭhā rajasi jinakulāvāhana preṣaṇa ca /
analyzed: homaḥ mantra pratiṣṭhā rajasi jina kula āvāhana preṣaṇa ca
translated: Homa, mantra consecration, in the dust, invoking and dispatching the Victorious Ones' family,

analyzed: mudrā siddhi dadāti sarva mudrā prasaṅge
translated: The attainment of mudrā bestows the supreme bliss of the powerful one, in the context of all mudrās.

original: tasmāt tad bhāvanīya pratidinasamaye yoginā mokṣahetoḥ //
analyzed: tasmāt tat prati dina samaye yoginā mokṣa hetoḥ
translated: Therefore, that should be contemplated by the yogi at the time of each day, for the sake of liberation.

original: mūrcchā nidrā praviṣṭa bhavati narapate niḥsvabhāva svacitta /
analyzed: mūrcchā nidrā praviṣṭa bhavati narapate niḥsvabhāva svacitta
translated: O King, when one enters into sleep and deep sleep, one's own mind is without intrinsic nature.

original: jāgrāyā sasvabhāva prakaṭayati na tat prāṇinā mokṣamārgam /
analyzed: prakaṭayati na tat prāṇinā mokṣa mārgam
translated: When one is awake, it manifests as having intrinsic nature, but that does not reveal the path of liberation to living beings.

original: bhāvābhāvairvibhinna na hi samasukhada yoginā cittavajram /
analyzed: bhāva abhāvaiḥ vibhinna na hi sama sukha da yoginā citta vajram
translated: The mind-vajra is not differentiated by existence and non-existence, and is the equal bliss of the yogin.

original: svaprajñāliṅgita yat sahajasukhagata mokṣada tat svacittam //
analyzed: sva prajñā liṅgita yat sahaja sukha gata mokṣa da tat sva cittam
translated: That which is embraced by one's own wisdom, gone to the state of innate bliss, is the giver of liberation, one's own mind.

original: sarvavidhakṛtrimopāyān parityajya sahajasukhasvarūpacittātmakeṣṭadeva tridhātukāyātmakasvaprajñayā āliṅgya caturānandānubhava yaḥ kurūte /
analyzed: sarvavidha kṛtrima upāyān parityajya sahaja sukha sva rūpa citta ātmaka iṣṭadeva tri dhātu kāya ātmaka sva prajñayā āliṅgya catur ānanda anubhava yaḥ kurūte
translated: Abandoning all artificial means, he who experiences the four joys by embracing the desired deity, which is the mind in the nature of innate bliss, with one's own wisdom, which has the nature of the three realms and the body,

analyzed: tasya uttama sādhakasya sa sādhanā vidhiḥ
translated: for that excellent practitioner, that is the method of practice.

original: madhyendriyaḥ sādhakaḥ kālacakrayuganaddhadevarūpeṇa bhāvanāṅkurūte tathā ca jñānamayamātāpitrorlalāṭe candramasi śvetavarṇe /
analyzed: madhya indriyaḥ sādhakaḥ kāla cakra yuga naddha deva rūpeṇa bhāvanāṅkurūte tathā ca jñāna maya mātā pitroḥ lalāṭe candramasi śveta varṇe
translated: The practitioner of medium faculties practices in the form of the deity of the Kalachakra Yuganaddha, and in the same way, on the forehead of the wisdom mother and father, in the moon, which is white,

original: om kaṇṭhe sūryopari raktavarṇe 'āḥ' citte ca rāhorūpari kṛṣṇavarṇe ha nābhau agnau pītavarṇe ho guhyendriye jñānopari nīlavarṇe 'svā' śīrṣe cākāśopari śyāmavarṇe 'hā' ityakṣarāṇi nyasti /
analyzed: om kaṇṭhe sūrya upari rakta varṇe āḥ citte ca rāhoḥ ūru upari kṛṣṇa varṇe ha nābhau agnau pīta varṇe ho guhya indriye jñāna upari nīla varṇe svā śīrṣe ca ākāśa upari śyāma varṇe hā iti akṣarāṇi nyasti
translated: Om in the throat, above the sun, which is red, Ah in the mind, above Rahu, which is black, Ha in the navel, in the fire, which is yellow, Ho in the organ of procreation, above the wisdom, which is blue, Sva in the head, above the space, which is dark, Ha - these syllables are placed.

analyzed: madhyendriya sādhakasya anusmṛti sādhanā iyam eva
translated: This is the practice of recollection for the practitioner of medium faculties.

original: adhamendriyaḥ sādhakaḥ caṇḍālīyogena ānandacatuṣṭaya sākṣātkṛtya mahāsukha cānubhūya taddārdyamavāptumasamartho'sti /
analyzed: adhama indriyaḥ sādhakaḥ caṇḍālī yogena ānanda catuṣṭaya sākṣātkṛtya mahā sukha ca anubhūya tad dārdyam avāptum asamarthaḥ asti
translated: The inferior-faculty practitioner, unable to attain stability in the great bliss experienced by directly realizing the four joys through the practice of a caṇḍālī, should rely on a karmamudrā.

analyzed: atas tena karma mudrā sevyā bhavati
translated: Therefore, he should practice with a karmamudrā.

original: kālacakre samuktam sevyā''dau karmamudrā jinasahajasukhasyāsya vṛddhyarthahetoḥ /
analyzed: kālacakre samuktam sevya ādau karma mudrā jina sahaja sukhasya asya vṛddhi artha hetoḥ
translated: It is said in the Kālacakra: At the beginning, one should practice with a karmamudrā for the sake of increasing this innate bliss of the Victorious Ones.

original: madhye prāṇapraveśaḥ saraviśaśigaterbandhana savyavāme citta mudrāprasaṅge paramasukhagata vajrasambodhana ca /
analyzed: madhye prāṇa praveśaḥ sa ravi śaśi gateḥ bandhana savya vāme citta mudrā prasaṅge parama sukha gata vajra sambodhana ca
translated: In the middle, one should practice prāṇāyāma, binding the sun and moon in the right and left, and the mind in the union with the mudrā, abiding in supreme bliss, and the vajra-awakening.

original: padye vajradhvanirvā svakarasalilajollālana saukhyahetor bījātyāgaḥ sasaukhyo maraṇabhayaharaḥ śrīgurorvaktrametat //
analyzed: padye vajra dhvaniḥ vā sva kara salilaja ullālana saukhya hetoḥ bīja a tyāgaḥ sa saukhyaḥ maraṇa bhaya haraḥ śrī guroḥ vaktram etat
translated: In the end, one should practice the vajra-sound, the delight of one's own hands and water, for the sake of happiness, and the non-abandonment of the seed, blissful, removing the fear of death. This is the face of the glorious guru.

original: ato'ya sādhakaḥ karmamudrā sasevya vāyu ca madhyamāmārge baddhvā punarmudrāyogena ānandānubhūti prāpnoti /
analyzed: sādhakaḥ karmamudrā vāyu ca madhyamā mārge baddhvā punar mudrā yogena ānanda anubhūti prāpnoti
translated: Therefore, this practitioner, having practiced with a karmamudrā, should bind the vāyu in the middle path again through the yoga of the mudrā and attain the experience of bliss.

analyzed: śukra sravitvā śirasaḥ lalāṭa paryanta prāptiḥ ānandaḥ asti
translated: The emission of semen reaching up to the forehead from the head is bliss.

original: lalāṭācca kaṇṭha hṛdaya ca yāvatprāptiḥ paramānandaḥ tataśca guhyendriya yāvat prāptirviramānandaḥ tadagre ca vajramaṇiparyantaprāptiḥ sahajānando'sti
analyzed: lalāṭāt ca kaṇṭha hṛdaya ca yāvat prāptiḥ paramānandaḥ tatas ca guhya indriya yāvat prāptiḥ virama ānandaḥ tad agre ca vajramaṇi paryanta prāptiḥ sahaja ānandaḥ asti
translated: And from the forehead to the throat and heart, there is the attainment of supreme bliss. Then from the secret organ up to the end of the vajra jewel, there is the innate bliss.

analyzed: tad tad sthāneṣu śukra gati avarodhanam eva mahā sukha prāptiḥ arthāt citta vajra prātisādhanā vartate
translated: The obstruction of the flow of semen in those places is the attainment of great bliss, and the mental vajra practice is implied.

analyzed: samādhiḥ sama sthitiḥ eva sama dhāraṇam eva samādhiḥ
translated: Samādhi is the state of equality itself, the state of equal retention itself is samādhi.
The state of being free from the duality of object and subject, the state of being without the difference between object and subject, is the meaning of samādhi.
The purpose of cultivating samādhi is the expansion of great bliss.

original: vipākakāya ca dharmadhātau pariśodhya viṣayaviṣayyadvayajñānakāyasya prāptikaraṇam /
analyzed: vipākakāya ca dharmadhātau pariśodhya viṣaya viṣayya dvaya jñāna kāyasya prāpti karaṇam
translated: Purifying the body of karmic ripening in the dharmadhātu is the means of attaining the body of non-dual knowledge of object and subject.

original: prajñāmahāsukhasya sarvākāravaropetajñānasya ca dvaitābhāsarahitayuganaddhānubhūtireva samādheḥ svarūpam /
analyzed: prajñā mahā sukhasya sarva ākāra vara upeta jñānasya ca dvaita ābhāsa rahita yuga naddha anubhūtiḥ eva samādheḥ svarūpam
translated: The nature of samādhi is the experience of the union of the wisdom of great bliss endowed with all supreme aspects and the wisdom free from the appearance of duality.

analyzed: guhyasamājottara tantre ca uktam prajñā upāya samāpatyā sarva bhāvān samāsatas
translated: And it is said in the Guhyasamāja Utterance Tantra: By the union of wisdom and method, all existences are, in brief,

analyzed: sahṛtya piṇḍa yogena bimba madhye vibhāvanam
translated: Having grasped the union with the essence, the visualization in the middle of the image,

analyzed: iti
translated: The instantaneous attainment of knowledge is called concentration.

analyzed: samādhi anusmṛtibhyā sākṣātkṛta akṣara sukha vistāraḥ dṛda tā prāptiḥ ca jāyate
translated: By means of concentration and recollection, the expansion of the bliss of the realized syllable is born, and the attainment of firmness.

original: ato'nusmṛteḥ sādhakānā bhedatrayamiva samādherapi bhedatraya bhavati /
analyzed: atas anusmṛteḥ sādhakānā bheda trayam iva samādheḥ api bheda traya bhavati
translated: Therefore, for the practitioners, just as there are three divisions of recollection, so there are three divisions of concentration as well.

original: sādhakaḥ karmamudrājñānamudrāmahāmudrābhiḥ sārdha samāpattau sthitvā anusmṛtiyogena sākṣātkṛtākṣarasukhasya vistāra labhate /
analyzed: sādhakaḥ karmamudrā jñānamudrā mahāmudrābhiḥ sārdha samāpattau sthitvā anusmṛti yogena sākṣātkṛta akṣara sukhasya vistāra labhate
translated: The practitioner, abiding in union with the karma-mudra, jnana-mudra, and maha-mudra, attains the expansion of the bliss of the realized syllable through the yoga of recollection.

original: yathā yathākṣarasukhadṛdatāprāptistadvistāraśca prāpyate tathā tathā sūkṣmavikalpānā kṣayo jāyate /
analyzed: yathā yathā akṣara sukha dṛda tā prāptiḥ tad vistāraḥ ca prāpyate tathā tathā sūkṣma vikalpānā kṣayaḥ jāyate
translated: As much as the firmness of the bliss of the syllable and its expansion is attained, to that extent the destruction of subtle conceptual thoughts is born.

analyzed: ante ca sādhakaḥ advayam āpnoti
translated: And in the end, the practitioner attains non-duality.

original: asmādeva cāśuddhatilaka kṣīyate vipākakāyasya ca pariśuddhyā idameva śarīra iṣṭadevakālacakre jñānamaye parivartate /
analyzed: asmāt eva ca aśuddha tilaka kṣīyate vipāka kāyasya ca pariśuddhyā idam eva śarīre iṣṭadeva kālacakre jñāna maye parivartate
translated: And from this very [non-duality], the impure bindu is destroyed, and by the purification of the fruitional body, this very body transforms into the wheel of deities and time, which is made of knowledge.

analyzed: samādheḥ ṣaḍaṅga yogasya ca idam eva falam
translated: This is the fruit of concentration and the yoga of the six branches.

analyzed: samādhiḥ api nusmṛtiḥ iva trividhā
translated: Concentration, like recollection, is also threefold.

original: atrāpi karmamudrā sasevya jñānamudrā ca sasevya mahāmudrāyā samāhitya sādhanā kriyate /
analyzed: atra api karmamudrā sasevya jñānamudrā ca sasevya mahāmudrāyā samāhitya sādhanā kriyate
translated: Here also, the practice of the karmamudra and the practice of the jnanamudra are done for the sake of attaining the mahamudra.

original: anusmṛtyā yanmahāsukha sādhakaḥ prāpnoti tatra samādhiyogena dṛdatā prāpyate /
analyzed: anusmṛtyā yat mahāsukha sādhakaḥ prāpnoti tatra samādhi yogena dṛdatā prāpyate
translated: What is attained by the practitioner of great bliss through recollection is attained with firmness through the yoga of samadhi.

original: karmamudrāsevanena samādhisādhanāviṣaye uttarakālacakre pratipāditam varṣārdhe śvetakuṣṭha harati varatanau mantriṇā ki tadanyat prajñāsaṅge svacitta skhalitamapi sadā prāṇavāyornirodhāt /
analyzed: karma mudrā sevanena samādhi sādhanā viṣaye uttara kālacakre pratipāditam varṣa ardhe śveta kuṣṭha harati vara tanau mantriṇā ki tat anyat prajñā saṅge sva citta skhalitam api sadā prāṇa vāyoḥ nirodhāt
translated: In the matter of attaining samadhi through the practice of the karmamudra, it has been taught in the Uttarakalacakra that the mantra practitioner can remove white leprosy in an excellent body in half a year, what else can he do? By stopping the life-force wind, he always removes the faults of his own mind.

original: saptayabdā jarā vai harati sapalitā cārdhavarṣaprapūrṇe ca dvivarṣaprapūrṇe
analyzed: saptayabdāḥ jarā vai harati sa palitā ca ardha varṣa prapūrṇe ca dvi varṣa prapūrṇe
translated: In seven years, he removes old age along with gray hair, in half a year, and in two years,

analyzed: mudrā siddhiḥ tad ūrdhva bhavati kati dinaiḥ mārga citta prasaṅgāt
translated: the attainment of the mudra occurs after that in a few days due to the flow of the mind of the path.

original: jñānamudrāsevanasya sādhanā sādhanāpaṭale ittha varṇitā mudrā māyānurūpā manasi ca gagane rūpavad darpaṇe ca trailokya bhāsayantī taḍidanilanibhānekaraśmīn sfurantī /
analyzed: jñāna mudrā sevanasya sādhanā sādhanā paṭale varṇitā mudrā māyā anurūpā manasi ca gagane rūpavat darpaṇe ca trailokya bhāsayantī taḍit anila nibhān eka raśmīn sfurantī
translated: The practice of the jnanamudra has been described in the Sadhanapatala in this way: The mudra, which is like an illusion, shines in the mind, in the sky, and in a mirror, illuminating the three worlds, flashing with many rays like lightning and wind.

original: bāhye deheṣvabhinnā viṣayavirahitā māsamātrāmbarasthā citta cetomayālliṅgayati ca jagato'nekarūpasya saikā //
analyzed: bāhye deheṣu abhinnā viṣaya virahitā māsa mātra ambara sthā cetaḥ mayān liṅgayati ca jagataḥ uneka rūpasya sā ekā
translated: In external bodies, undivided, devoid of objects, remaining in the sky for a month, she unites with the linga of the mind and mental factors of the many-formed world.

original: mahāmudrayā sāka sādhanāvidhirapi tatraivopadiṣṭa tyaktvemā karmamudrāsakaluṣahṛdayā kalpitā jñānamudrā samyaksambodhihetorjinavarajananī bhāvayed divyamudrām /
analyzed: mahāmudrayā sāka sādhanā vidhiḥ api tatra evā upadiṣṭa tyaktvā imā karmamudrā sa kaluṣa hṛdayā kalpitā jñāna mudrā samyaksambodhi hetoḥ jinavara jananī bhāvayet divya mudrām
translated: The method of practice along with the great mudra is also taught there, abandoning this impure heart of the karma mudra, the wisdom mudra is imagined, the divine mudra should be contemplated as the cause of perfect enlightenment, the mother of the excellent victors.

original: nirlepā nirvikārā khasamahatatamā vyāpinī yogagamyā kūṭasthā jñātejā bhavakaluṣaharā kālacakrānuviddhām //
analyzed: nirlepā nirvikārā kha samahatatamā vyāpinī yoga gamyā kūṭasthā jñā tejāḥ bhava kaluṣa harā kālacakra anuviddhām
translated: Stainless, changeless, equal to the great void, all-pervading, accessible through yoga, abiding in the peak, of the essence of knowledge, removing the impurities of worldly existence, penetrated by the wheel of time.

analyzed: samādhi aṅga sādhanā vidhiḥ anusmṛti sadṛśaḥ eva
translated: The method of practice for the limbs of samadhi is like recollection itself.

original: etad vaiśiṣṭya yadatrānusmṛtyaṅgena parijñāte yuganaddhatatve dṛdatā prāptavyā /
analyzed: etat vaiśiṣṭya yat atra anusmṛti aṅgena parijñāte dṛdatā prāptavyā
translated: This is the distinction here, that in the reality of the union, which is fully known by the limb of recollection, firmness is to be attained.

analyzed: guhya samāje ca api uktam samādhi vāsi tā mātre nirāvaraṇavān bhavet
translated: And it is said in the Guhyasamaja: By merely being suffused with samadhi, one becomes free from obscurations.

original: ittha ṣaḍaṅgayogasyāṅgatraya kāyavākcittāni vajradeha ca prāpayati /
analyzed: ittha kāya vāc cittāni vajra deha ca prāpayati
translated: Thus, the six-limbed yoga causes the body, speech, and mind to attain the vajra body.

analyzed: aṅga trayam ca tat dārdya prāpayati
translated: And the three limbs cause the attainment of its indestructibility.

original: śarīre'smin advayatantrasādhakaḥ yuganaddhakālacakre pariṇataḥ san paramapade avatiṣṭhate /
analyzed: śarīresmin advaya tantra sādhakaḥ yuga naddha kāla cakre pariṇataḥ san parama pade avatiṣṭhate
translated: In this body, the practitioner of the non-dual tantra, having become perfected in the yoga of simultaneity, abides in the supreme state.

analyzed: amum eva advaya tattva sādhanā vidhim ādhārīkṛtya varṇitam
translated: This very method of practicing the non-dual truth has been taken as the basis and described.

original: uparyuktapramāṇairida spaṣṭa yat bustonena svayogavidhisamarthane kālacakratantrasamājottaratantrasekoddeśaṭīkāśca sarvatroddhṛtāḥ santi
analyzed: upari ukta pramāṇaiḥ idam spaṣṭa yat bustonena sva yoga vidhi samarthane kālacakra tantra samāja uttara tantra seka uddeśa ṭīkāḥ ca sarvatra uddhṛtāḥ santi
translated: It is clear from the above proofs that Bu-ston has quoted the Kalachakra Tantra, Samaja Tantra, Uttara Tantra, and Sekoddesha Tika everywhere in support of his own yoga method.

original: itthamatra pradhānataḥ bustona dvārā pratipādita ṣaḍaṅgayogavidhimādhārīkṛtya varṇitam /
analyzed: ittham atra pradhānatas bustona dvārā pratipādita ṣaḍaṅga yoga vidhim ādhārīkṛtya varṇitam
translated: Thus, the method of six-limbed yoga taught by Bu-ston has been taken as the basis and described here mainly.

original: etadvistarastu kālacakraṭīkāvimalaprabhāyāḥ sādhanāpaṭale jñānapaṭale ca vyadhīyata /
analyzed: etat vistaraḥ tu kālacakra ṭīkā vimalaprabhāyāḥ sādhanā paṭale jñāna paṭale ca vyadhīyata
translated: This is elaborated in the Sadhana chapter and Jnana chapter of the Vimalaprabha commentary on the Kalachakra Tantra.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭhaḥ paricchedaḥ advaya tantrasya
translated: The sixth chapter of the special two Tibetan lineages of the non-dual tantra

original: śamakaparamparā etatparamparāyāḥ sādhanāpaddhateḥ sūtrapātaḥ ḥ āryadevenākāri /
analyzed: śamaka paramparā etad paramparāyāḥ sādhanā paddhateḥ sūtrapātaḥ āryadevena akāri
translated: The lineage of Shama-ka: The sutra-patah of this lineage's method of practice was composed by Aryadeva.

original: parañcāsyāḥ pracārasya śreyaḥ sarvaprathama dakṣiṇabhāratasya vidarbhacarasihākhyaprāntotpannasya narasihasyaiva jedima pāgyagaravā jāyate
analyzed: paran ca asyāḥ pracārasya śreyaḥ sarva prathama dakṣiṇa bhāratasya vidarbha carasiha ākhya prānta utpannasya narasihasya eva  / jāyate
translated: And the greatest merit in the propagation of this [religion] is due to the very first of all, to Narasimha, who was born in the border region called Vidarbhacharasiha in South India.

analyzed: anena catur pañcāśata adhika gurūbhyaḥ śikṣā lābhi
translated: And he received instruction from more than fifty-four teachers.

analyzed: aya ca pañcaśaḥ tibbata jagāma
translated: And he went to Tibet five times.

analyzed: khrīṣṭa abdāt ī paryanta ekaviśati varṣāṇi
translated: He lived in Tibet for twenty-one years,

original: tibbatadeśe nyavasat tatra cāsya dharmapracārakendra dīṅrīprānta eva /
analyzed: tibbata deśe nyavasat tatra ca asya dharma pracāraka indra dīṅrī prānte eva
translated: and there, too, in the very border region of Dingri, he was the center for the propagation of the Dharma.

original: mṛtyukāle'pi aya dīṅarīvāsinaḥ sambodhayan śata ślokān samupādiśat /
analyzed: mṛtyu kāle pi aya dīṅarīvāsinaḥ sambodhayan śata ślokān samupādiśat
translated: Even at the time of his death, he instructed the residents of Dingri with the Hundred Stanzas.

analyzed: yat ca atīva preraṇa āspadam
translated: And that is a very inspiring [text].

analyzed: śamaka paramparāyāḥ dvau āmnāyau bhāratīya śamaka paramparā
translated: There are two traditions of the lineage of Shakyamuni: the Indian lineage of Shakyamuni,

analyzed: bhoṭa deśīyā yoginī macīgala baḍona paramparā
translated: and the lineage of the Tibetan yoginī Machik Labdrön.

analyzed: prathamā ca atra āryadevena adhiṣṭhitā
translated: And the first is presided over by Āryadeva.

analyzed: dvitīyā paramparā yoginīm acīgataḥ prācalat
translated: The second lineage proceeded from the yoginī Machik.

original: tibbatasya labchīnāmakasthāne etadutpannatvāt svakṣetranāmnā etannāma labchīpradīpaḥ macīga labaḍona 🔽ityajāyata /
analyzed: tibbatasya labchī nāmaka sthāne etat utpanna tvāt sva kṣetra nāmnā etad nāma labchī pradīpaḥ  iti ajāyata
translated: Since it originated in the place called Labshi in Tibet, it got its name after its native place, Labshi Pradip. It was born as Machig Labdrön.

original: macīgalabaḍonaḥ trayoviśativarṣāvasthāyā bhāratasya kosalapradeśāt tibbatadeśa prāpa /
analyzed: macīgalabaḍonaḥ trayoviśati varṣa avasthāyāḥ bhāratasya kosala pradeśāt tibbata deśa prāpa
translated: Machig Labdrön reached Tibet from the Kosala region of India at the age of twenty-three.

original: ācāryagurūbhadreṇa sāka vivāhito'bhūt yaśca buddhakapālasādhaka āsīt /
analyzed: ācārya guru ubhadreṇa sāka vivāhitaḥ bhūt yaḥ ca buddha kapāla sādhakaḥ āsīt
translated: She was married to Acharya Guru Bhadra, who was a practitioner of the Buddha's skull.

original: asya vistṛtaḥ jīvanaparicayaḥ aṣṭasaptaticchedakavivṛttināmake granthe samupalabhyate /
analyzed: asya vistṛtaḥ jīvana paricayaḥ aṣṭasaptati chedaka vivṛtti nāmake granthe samupalabhyate
translated: A detailed account of her life can be found in the text called the Commentary on the Seventy-Seven Verses.
The method of practice, the text that forms the basis of the lineage of pacification, is the Heart Sutra of the Perfection of Wisdom.

analyzed: atra tasmāt jñātavyaḥ prajñāpāramitā mahā mantraḥ vidyā mantraḥ anuttara mantraḥ
translated: Here, it should be known that the great mantra of the perfection of wisdom, the mantra of knowledge, the unsurpassed mantra,

original: asamasamamantraḥ sarvaduḥkhapraśamanamantraḥ ityasmin praśamanaśabdasyaiva śamakaparamparā susthāpitā'bhavat /
analyzed: asama sama mantraḥ sarva duḥkha praśamana mantraḥ iti asmin praśamana śabdasya eva śamaka paramparā su sthāpitā abhavat
translated: the mantra equal to the unequaled, the mantra that pacifies all suffering - in this, the lineage of pacification has been well established by the word pacification itself.

original: āryadevaḥ prajñāpāramitāhṛdayasūtramādhārīkṛtya pañcāśatślokeṣu āryaprajñāpāramitopadeśanāmakārikā viracayya śamakaparamparā pracārayāmāsa
analyzed: ārya devaḥ prajñāpāramitā hṛdaya sūtram ādhārīkṛtya pañcāśat ślokeṣu ārya prajñāpāramitā upadeśa nāma kārikāḥ viracayya śamaka paramparā pracārayāmāsa
translated: Āryadeva, taking the Heart Sutra of the Perfection of Wisdom as the basis, composed the fifty verses called Ārya Prajñāpāramitā Upadeśa Nāma Kārikā and propagated the lineage of peace.

original: atra ca bhāvanāvidhiviṣaye suspaṣṭīkṛta cakṣurādīndriyāṇi balād nāvaroddhavyāni /
analyzed: atra ca bhāvanā vidhi viṣaye cakṣuḥ ādi indriyāṇi balāt na avaroddhavyāni
translated: And here, in the domain of the method of meditation, the eyes and other senses should not be forcibly obstructed, as they are clearly illuminated.

analyzed: viṣaye pratyakṣa pravṛtti sadṛśa agraha binā nirvikalpa svarūpeṇa stheyam
translated: One should remain in the form of non-conceptualization, without grasping similar to the direct engagement in the object.

analyzed: abhiniveśa rāga dveṣa krodha ādi mārāṇā smṛti samprajanya rūpi kuṭhāreṇa chedana kartavyam
translated: The cutting should be done with the axe of mindfulness and awareness, cutting off the afflictions of attachment, aversion, anger, and so on.

original: prajñāpāramitāprāptirbahirna bhavati sā tu bhāvābhāvarahitā nirlakṣaṇā prakṛtiprabhāsvarā svacittarūpaiva /
analyzed: prajñāpāramitā prāptiḥ bahis na bhavati sā tu bhāva abhāva rahitā nirlakṣaṇā prakṛti prabhāsvarā sva citta rūpā eva
translated: The attainment of the perfection of wisdom does not come from outside, but rather it is the nature of one's own mind, free from existence and non-existence, devoid of characteristics, luminous by nature.

original: śūnyakāśo yāvadvyāptaḥ tāvadeva svacitta vyāpya sthāpanīyam /
analyzed: śūnya kāśaḥ yāvat vyāptaḥ tāvat eva vyāpya sthāpanīyam
translated: The space that is pervaded by emptiness should be pervaded by one's own mind to that extent and should be established.

original: svacittasya yathārthyabodhe sati tattaraṅgarūpirāgadveṣādicaitasikaguṇānā prahāṇasyāvaśyakatā na bhavati /
analyzed: sva cittasya yathārthya bodhe sati tad taraṅga rūpi rāga dveṣa ādi caitasika guṇānā prahāṇasya āvaśyaka tā na bhavati
translated: When the truth of one's own mind is realized, then the abandonment of the mental qualities such as attachment, aversion, and so on, which are in the form of waves, is not necessary.

analyzed: te ca svayam nirūdhyante
translated: And they are naturally obstructed.

original: yathā prāṇeṣu nāśiteṣu satsu anyendriyāṇā nāśasyāvaśyakatā na jāyate /
analyzed: yathā prāṇeṣu nāśiteṣu satsu anya indriyāṇām nāśasya āvaśyaka tā na jāyate
translated: Just as when the life is destroyed, the necessity of destruction of other senses does not arise.

analyzed: nāmasaṅgītau api uktam
translated: It is said in the Namasamgiti also: The pacifier of the suffering of the three sufferings, the infinite, the one who has attained the three liberations,

analyzed: sarva avarana nirmuktaḥ ākāśa samatā gataḥ
translated: Freed from all obscurations, gone to the state of space.

original: duḥkhatrayasyābhighātāya śamanāya ca nirāvaraṇagaganasadṛśe svacitte stheyam /
analyzed: duḥkha trayasya abhighātāya śamanāya ca nirāvaraṇa gagana sadṛśe sva citte stheyam
translated: One should abide in one's own mind, which is free from obscurations and similar to space, for the sake of overcoming and pacifying the three types of suffering.

original: svarūpataḥ sakalajagataḥ ādito'nutpannaprabhāsvarasvarūpatve satyapi ajñānarūpivāyunā bhramitvā sattvo duḥkhabhāg bhavati /
analyzed: svarūpataḥ sakala jagataḥ āditas unutpanna prabhāsvara sva rūpa tve sati api ajñāna rūpi vāyunā bhramitvā sattvaḥ duḥkha bhāj bhavati
translated: Although in its own nature, the entire world is primordially unarisen and has the nature of clear light, due to being whirled around by the wind of ignorance, a sentient being becomes subject to suffering.

original: ataḥ ajñānarūpivāyupravāha prabhāsvare vinilīyādvayatattve samavasthitireva śamakabhāvanāyāstattvam /
analyzed: atas ajñāna rūpi vāyu pravāha prabhāsvare vinilīya advaya tattve samavasthitiḥ eva śamaka bhāvanāyāḥ tattvam
translated: Therefore, the essence of the meditation on pacification is to abide in the non-dual reality, having melted the stream of the wind of ignorance into the clear light.

original: yoginīmacīgalabaḍonaḥ acakathat yaccharīra śavasama mattvā cittasya nirāvṛttagaganasadṛśasthāpanenaiva tattva sākṣātkriyate /
analyzed: acakathat yat śarīra cittasya nirāvṛtta gagana sadṛśa sthāpanena eva sākṣātkriyate
translated: The Yoginīmañjarī says: Having regarded the body as equal to a corpse, by merely establishing the mind in the sky-like state free from obscurations, reality is directly realized.

analyzed: śamaka paramparāyā tattva sādhanā pāramitā naya mantra naya sahajīyā iti tritaya paddhatyā vidhīyate
translated: The means of accomplishing reality through the lineage of pacification is performed through the three methods of the Pāramitānaya, Mantrayāna, and Sahajayāna.

original: yathā bodhisattvamāninaḥ bodhicittaprābalya dyotayanti tathā ca tadvicāradṛṣṭivyavahārādayo bodhicittāt preritā bhavanti /
analyzed: yathā bodhisattva māninaḥ dyotayanti tathā ca tad vicāra dṛṣṭi vyavahāra ādayaḥ bodhi cittāt preritāḥ bhavanti
translated: Just as those who pride themselves on being bodhisattvas illuminate the strength of the bodhicitta, so too, the views, conduct, and so on that are investigated by them are impelled by the bodhicitta.

analyzed: tathā eva etat śamaka paramparāyām api nirdvandva nirvikalpa sthitayoḥ āvaśyaka tva preryyate
translated: In the same way, in this lineage of peace, the necessity of the states of non-duality and non-conceptuality is impelled.

analyzed: sādhanāṅge ete chedaka paddhatim anusaranti
translated: These [states] follow the method of the cutter in the branch of means.

analyzed: kaḥ ca chedakaḥ
translated: And what is the cutter?

analyzed: chedaka abhiprāyaḥ tu ātma grāha bhedanam arthāt tad parityāgaḥ
translated: The intention of the cutter is, in fact, the breaking of the grasping of self and the abandonment of that.

analyzed: ātma grāhaḥ eva bhava hetuḥ
translated: The grasping of self is the cause of existence.

original: yato hyahaṅkārabhāvanodayena sahasā madgṛhamatparivāraprabhṛtyagrahāṇā vistāro bhavati /
analyzed: yatas hi ahaṅkāra bhāvanā udayena sahasā mad gṛha mad parivāra prabhṛtyagrahāṇā vistāraḥ bhavati
translated: For when the arising of the cultivation of egoism occurs, suddenly the grasping of my house, my retinue, and so on expands.

original: tadartha vibhinnakarmāṇi kurūte bhavacakre ca badhyate /
analyzed: tad artha vibhinna karmāṇi kurūte bhava cakre ca badhyate
translated: For that purpose, one performs various actions and is bound in the wheel of existence.

original: etatpratipakṣe yatra pāramitānaye yuktiprayogeṇa niṣprapañcasya pratipādana kriyate tatraiva mantranaye sthāvarajaṅgamayoḥ rūpa parivartya utpattiniṣpannakramau bhāvyete /
analyzed: etad pratipakṣe yatra pāramitā naye yukti prayogeṇa niṣprapañcasya pratipādana kriyate tatra eva mantra naye sthāvara jaṅgamayoḥ utpatti niṣpanna kramau bhāvyete
translated: In the antidote to that, where the teaching of non-elaboration is made by the application of reasoning in the method of the perfections, there in the method of mantra, the sequence of arising and accomplishment is cultivated by transforming the form of the immovable and the moving.

analyzed: śamaka paramparāyām tu kriyate
translated: The practice of the two methods of the lineage of peace is done.

original: sahaiva ca svaśariratvaca svarṇadīpa hastāpādyādyaṅgāni jambvādicaturdvīpān rūdhiram aṣṭaguṇairyukta jala māsa cāṣṭamāṅgalika cihna pṛṣṭhāsthi sumerūparvata cakṣuṣī ca sūryacandropame mattvā bhāvanayā etān sarvāniṣṭadevāya samarpayanti sādhakāḥ /
analyzed: saha eva ca svarṇa dīpa hastā pādya ādi aṅgāni jambu ādi catur dvīpān rūdhiram aṣṭaguṇaiḥ yukta jala māsa ca aṣṭamāṅgalika cihna pṛṣṭhāsthi sumerū parvata cakṣuṣī ca sūrya candra upame bhāvanayā etān sarvān iṣṭadevāya samarpayanti sādhakāḥ
translated: And along with their own skin, the limbs like hands, feet, etc., the four continents like Jambu, the blood, the water endowed with eight qualities, the back bone with the eight auspicious signs, the mountain Sumeru, the eyes resembling the sun and moon, considering all these as offerings to the undesirable gods, the practitioners offer them with meditation.

original: anantabhavacakrasyaitat śṛṅkhalāyām eva ko'pi prāṇī nāvaśiṣyate yaḥ kiñcidayonau svaya mātva pitva ca nālabhata /
analyzed: ananta bhava cakrasya etat śṛṅkhalāyām eva kaḥ api prāṇī na avaśiṣyate yaḥ kiñcid ayonau svayam mātva pitva ca na alabhata
translated: In this very chain of the endless cycle of births, there remains no living being whatsoever who has not taken birth in some womb as a mother or father.

original: sarveṣā ṛṇamasmadupari bhavati tat ṛṇarāhitatyāya chedakaparamparāsādhakaḥ cetanaśarīrāt sthūlaśarīrametat pṛthak kṛtvā prāṇināmicchānurūpa māsarūdhirādīnāsravānāsravadravyeṇa bhāvayitvā prāṇibhyaḥ samarpayati /
analyzed: sarveṣām ṛṇam asmat upari bhavati tat ṛṇa rāhitatyāya chedaka paramparā sādhakaḥ cetana śarīrāt sthūlaśarīram etat pṛthak kṛtvā māsa rūdhira ādīn āsrava anāsrava dravyeṇa bhāvayitvā prāṇibhyaḥ samarpayati
translated: The debt of all is upon us, for the sake of being free from that debt, the practitioner who cuts the lineage, having separated this gross body from the conscious body, having meditated on the blood, flesh, etc. according to the desires of living beings with the flowing and non-flowing substances, offers them to the living beings.

original: chedakaparamparāyāḥ sādhakaḥ śmaśānajalasroto anyatra vā gatvā sādhanāṅkurūte /
analyzed: chedaka paramparāyāḥ sādhakaḥ śmaśāna jala srotaḥ anyatra vā gatvā sādhanām kurūte
translated: The series of cutters, the practitioner goes to a cremation ground, a water source, or elsewhere and plants the sprout of practice.

original: śarīra pratyabhiniveśasya prahāṇāya śmaśāna gatvā svaśarīra māsarūdhirayoḥ piṇḍarūpeṇa dhyātvā bhūtapretapiśācādibhyaḥ samarpayati /
analyzed: śarīra pratyabhiniveśasya prahāṇāya śmaśāna gatvā sva śarīra māsa rūdhirayoḥ piṇḍa rūpeṇa dhyātvā bhūta preta piśāca ādibhyaḥ samarpayati
translated: In order to abandon attachment to the body, having gone to a cremation ground, one visualizes one's own body in the form of a lump of flesh and blood and offers it to ghosts, spirits, demons, and so on.

original: siddhamilārasapāmahodayaḥ chedakaparamparā suspaṣṭayan kathayatiśmaśānaikāntajalasrota ādiṣu kṛtā sādhanā bāhyachedikā śarirāṅgapratyaṅgānā prāṇibhyo bhojanarūpeṇa samarpaṇam /
analyzed: chedaka paramparā su spaṣṭayan kathayati śmaśāna ekānta jala srotaḥ ādiṣu kṛtā sādhanā bāhya chedikā prāṇibhyaḥ bhojana rūpeṇa samarpaṇam
translated: The glorious Siddha Milarepa, clearly explaining the series of cutters, says: The external cutter is the practice done in cremation grounds, at the end of water sources, and so on, which is the offering of the limbs and parts of the body to living beings in the form of food.

analyzed: ābhyantara chedikā sādhanā
translated: The internal cutter is the practice.

analyzed: ātma grāhasya ca sa mūla nāśaḥ eva paramārtha chedaka sādhanā ucyate
translated: The ultimate cutter is said to be the complete destruction of the grasping of self.

original: sārūpeṇeda vaktu śakya śatrurbahirna bhavati tattu svacittasyaiva śatrutvam /
analyzed: śatruḥ bahis na bhavati tat tu sva cittasya eva śatru tvam
translated: It is possible to say this in a similar way: An enemy is not external, but rather the mind itself is the enemy.

analyzed: svāntaḥ vidyamāna rāga dveṣa moha ādika prati śobhana aśobhana bhāvanā eva māraḥ
translated: The Mara that exists within one's own mind, the thoughts of good and bad regarding attachment, aversion, delusion, and so on, is the Mara.

original: tatsarvasya nāśaḥ sarvasya pūrṇataḥ tāṭasthyena nirdvandvātmakanirvikalpātmakatayā darśanameva sarvasādhanānā lakṣyam /
analyzed: tat sarvasya nāśaḥ sarvasya pūrṇataḥ tāṭasthyena nirdvandva ātmaka nirvikalpa ātmaka tayā darśanam eva sarva sādhanānām lakṣyam
translated: The destruction of all that, the complete, neutral, non-dual, non-discriminating vision of all, is the goal of all means.

analyzed: śamaka paramparā api sādhakam etad dṛṣṭi prati nayati
translated: The succession of peace also leads to this vision.

original: ñiṅmāparamparā āryadeśa parityajya śrāvakayānapratyekabuddhayānbodhisattvayānānā pāramitāyānavajrayāna🔽arthāt bauddhadharmasya sarvayānānā vikāsaḥ cet kutrāpi jātastarhi sa tibbatadeśe eva /
analyzed: ārya deśa parityajya  arthāt bauddha dharmasya vikāsaḥ ced kutra api jātaḥ tarhi sa tibbata deśe eva
translated: The succession of nine, abandoning the noble land, the vehicles of the hearers, solitary realizers, bodhisattvas, the perfection vehicle, vajra vehicle,🔽In other words, if the development of all the vehicles of Buddhism has taken place anywhere, it has taken place in Tibet.

original: tibbate sarvaprathama bauddhadharmapraveśaḥ samrāṭ sroṅcanagonpomahodayasya ī
analyzed: bauddha dharmapraveśaḥ
translated: The first entry of Buddhism into Tibet occurred

analyzed: samaye samabhūt  param ca eka varṣa anantara glaṅparamā buddha śāsana vyanāśayat
translated: during the time of Emperor Srongtsen Gampo.🔽Moreover, one year later, the Buddhist teachings were destroyed by Glang Dar Ma.

original: tadā ratnabhadramarapādharmamatyādayo naike vidyārthinaḥ bhāratavarṣamāgatya adhyayanādhyāpana ca kṛtvā tatra punaḥ bauddhadharma prācārayan
analyzed: tadā na eke vidyā arthinaḥ bhārata varṣam āgatya adhyayana adhyāpana ca kṛtvā tatra punar bauddha dharma prācārayan
translated: At that time, many seekers of knowledge such as Ratna, Bhadra, Dharmamati, and others came to India, studied and taught, and reintroduced Buddhism there.

original: ittha tibbatadeśe bauddhadharmasya dve parampare pracalite'bhūtām /
analyzed: tibbata deśe bauddha dharmasya dve parampae
translated: Thus, in Tibet, two traditions of Buddhism flourished.
The first tradition is called the Early Spread of the Ňiṅma

analyzed: dvitīyā ca parodayā saramā kathyate
translated: and the second is called the Later Spread of the Saṅma.

analyzed: dvitīya paramparāyā sampradāyāḥ vyakasan
translated: In the second tradition, four lineages arose, namely the Kargyu, Sakya, Kadam, and Pagyelug.

analyzed: pūrva udaya sampradāye ñ iṅ mā
translated: In the Early Spread tradition, the Ňiṅma

analyzed: vajrayāna pracāritam
translated: Vajrayāna was propagated.

original: itthamaneke tantragranthāḥ yeṣā kevala ñiṅmāsampradāye pracalanamabhavat ye ca ñiṅmāgyudabumanāmake sagrahe ṣaṭcatvāriśadgranthiṣu 🔽samupalabhyante /
analyzed: ittham aneke tantra granthāḥ kevala ñiṅmā sampradāye pracalanam abhavat ye ca sa grahe ṣaṭcatvāriśat granthiṣu  samupalabhyante
translated: Thus, many tantric texts circulated only in the Ňiṅma tradition, and which are found in the collection called Ňiṅma Gyudbum, consisting of forty-six volumes.

analyzed: teṣu ca prāmukhyam
translated: Among them, the Sarvadharmamahāśāntibodhicittakula-yārā-garbhaguhya-herūka-līlā-tantra-jñānaguhya-pradyotā are prominent.

analyzed: kargi uda sampradāye na eteṣām samāveśaḥ
translated: These are not included in the Kargyu tradition.

analyzed: atas ñiṅmā sampradāyasya tad sāhityasya ca paricaya pradānam āvaśyakam
translated: Therefore, it is necessary to provide an introduction to the Ňiṅma tradition and its related literature.

original: sampradāye'smin naike suvikhyātā anuvādakā siddhapurūṣāśca abhūvan /
analyzed: sampradāye smin na eke su vikhyātāḥ siddha purūṣāḥ ca abhūvan
translated: In this tradition, many well-known commentators and accomplished masters have appeared.

original: viśeṣeṇa aoḍiyānetyasyācāryaḥ padyasambhavaḥ mahāmahopādhyāyaḥ śāntarakṣitaśca tibbatadeśīyaṭhīsroṅcanadehucana ī
analyzed: viśeṣeṇa aoḍiyāna ityasya ācāryaḥ padya sambhavaḥ mahā mahā upādhyāyaḥ śāntarakṣitaḥ ca
translated: In particular, the teacher Padmasambhava of Oḍiviśa and the great preceptor Śāntarakṣita, both from the Tibetan region of Tsongkha,

original: rājñā tibbatadeśe samāmantritau /🔽etaddvayasya mārgadarśane samrāṭ samayasanāmaka vihāra nirmitavān atraiva ca kagyuratagyura
analyzed: rājñā tibbata deśe samāmantritau  etad dvayasya mārga darśane samrāj samayasa nāmaka vihāra nirmitavān atra eva ca
translated: were invited by the king to the Tibetan region.

analyzed: buddha vacanāni bhoṭa bhāṣāyām anūditāni
translated: For the guidance of these two, the emperor built a monastery named Samye, and here the Buddha's words were translated into the Tibetan language by Kawa Paltseg of Kaba and Chokro Lüi Gyaltsen of Chogro.

analyzed: śāntarakṣitaḥ yūnaḥ pravrājya tibbata deśe vinaya śāsanam akārṣīt
translated: Śāntarakṣita ordained the young ones in the Tibetan region and established the Vinaya teachings.

original: ācāryapadyasambhavaḥ pañcaviśatisakhyakān jevaṅa ñeraṅamahodayādīn vajrayāne abhyaṣicat ye cāgre siddhimāpnuvan /
analyzed: ācārya padya sambhavaḥ pañcaviśati sakhyakān jevaṅaḥ ñeraṅa mahodaya ādīn vajrayāne abhyaṣicat ye ca agre siddhim āpnuvan
translated: The teacher Padmasambhava consecrated twenty-five disciples, including Jeng Yeshé Gyaltsen and Ngen Nyiwa Gyaltsen, in the Vajrayāna, who later attained accomplishment.

original: tasyāmeva paramparāyā naike sādhakā ācāryā guptasthānād dharmaśāstragrahītāraḥ aṣṭottaraśata siddhā ājagmuḥ /
analyzed: tasyām eva paramparāyāḥ na eke sādhakāḥ ācāryāḥ gupta sthānāt dharmaśāstra grahītāraḥ aṣṭottaraśata siddhāḥ ājagmuḥ
translated: In that very lineage, many accomplished masters came from the hidden land of Dharmashri, having attained the one hundred and eight accomplishments.

analyzed: etad agre etad paramparāyā sarvajñaḥ loḍachenapā samabhūt
translated: Before this, in that very lineage, the omniscient Lodröchok appeared.

analyzed: ca sampradāyam imam ati samṛddham akarot
translated: And he made this tradition very prosperous.

analyzed: viśeṣeṇa sādhana aprādhānya pradadāti iya paramparā
translated: In particular, this lineage gives prominence to the means of accomplishment.

original: tibbatadeśe sarvādhikāḥ siddhapurūṣāḥ etasminneva sampradāye samabhavan /
analyzed: tibbata deśe sarva adhikāḥ siddha purūṣāḥ etasmin eva sampradāye samabhavan
translated: In the land of Tibet, all the most accomplished beings arose in this very tradition.

analyzed: ñ iṅ mā sampradāye nava yānāni mānyāni śrāvaka yānam
translated: In the Nyingma tradition, there are nine vehicles to be honored: the Hearer Vehicle,

analyzed: pratyekabudha yānam
translated: the Solitary Buddha Vehicle,

analyzed: bodhisattva yāna
translated: the Bodhisattva Vehicle,

analyzed: kriyātantrayāna
translated: the Action Tantra Vehicle,

analyzed: upāyayāna
translated: the Means Vehicle,

analyzed: yogatantrayāna
translated: the Yoga Tantra Vehicle,
the Great Yoga Tantra Vehicle,🔽the Unsurpassed Yoga Tantra Vehicle,

original: atiyogatantrayāna ca /🔽atra sakṣepeṇa etāni yānāni vimṛśyante yena ca tibbatasya etatprācīnaparamparāsādhanā prakāśitā bhavet /
analyzed: atiyoga tantra yāna ca  atra sa kṣepeṇa etāni yānāni vimṛśyante yena ca tibbatasya etad prācīna paramparā sādhanā prakāśitā bhavet
translated: and the Ati Yoga Tantra Vehicle.🔽Here, these vehicles are briefly examined, by which the ancient lineage of accomplishment of Tibet may be revealed.

analyzed: atra ukta nava yānānā krameṇa paricayaḥ prastūyate
translated: Here, the acquaintance with the nine vehicles mentioned is begun in order.

analyzed: samānyatas yāna śabda arthaḥ ārohaṇam
translated: The general meaning of the word yana is to ascend.

original: atra pratipāditāni yānāni kramaśaḥ asmān ūrdhva nayanti /
analyzed: atra pratipāditāni yānāni kramaśas asmān ūrdhva nayanti
translated: The vehicles taught here gradually lead us upward.

analyzed: tatas yānam iti ucyate
translated: Therefore, it is called a vehicle.

original: śrāvakayānam dharmātmakau grāhyagrāhakau paramārthe nirūpya svaya mokṣaprāptyāśayena aṣṭavidhaprātimokṣe ekaprakāraka kimapi śīla sagṛhya duṣcaryāmapahāya samādhinā citta karmayogya vidhāya caturāryasatyasya ṣoḍaśākāreṇa prajñābhāvanayā tatsākṣātkurūte yastasya falarūpeṇa srotāpatteḥ arhatpadaprāptimārgaḥ śrāvakayāna nigadyate /
analyzed: śrāvakayānam dharma ātmakau grāhya grāhakau paramārthe nirūpya svayam mokṣa prāpti āśayena aṣṭavidha prātimokṣe eka prakāraka kim api śīla sa gṛhya duṣcaryām apahāya samādhinā citta karma yogya vidhāya catur ārya satyasya ṣoḍaśa ākāreṇa prajñā bhāvanayā tat sākṣātkurūte yaḥ tasya fala rūpeṇa srotāpatteḥ arhat pada prāpti mārgaḥ śrāvakayāna nigadyate
translated: The Śrāvaka Vehicle: Having examined the apprehended object and apprehending subject as having the nature of phenomena in the ultimate truth, with the intention of attaining liberation oneself, one takes up some kind of discipline, either one of the eight forms of individual liberation or one of the five types of lay discipline, and having abandoned misconduct, one makes the mind fit for spiritual practice through concentration. Then, by cultivating wisdom through the sixteen aspects of the four noble truths, one realizes them. The path for attaining the stage of an arhat through the fruit of stream-entry is called the Śrāvaka Vehicle.

original: pratyekabuddhayānam atra kṣaṇamātra vijñāna paramārthe dṛṣṭvā ṣoḍaśākāreṣu caturāryasatyabhāvanā śrāvayānena sama vidhīyate /
analyzed: pratyekabuddha yānam atra kṣaṇa mātra vijñāna paramārthe dṛṣṭvā ṣoḍaśa ākāreṣu catur ārya satya bhāvanā śrāvayānena sama vidhīyate
translated: The Pratyekabuddha Vehicle: Having seen mere momentary consciousness as the ultimate truth here, the cultivation of the four noble truths through the sixteen aspects is carried out in the same way as in the Śrāvaka Vehicle.

original: parañcātra tadbhāvanayā sārdha gambhīrapratītyasamutpādasya samanvayātmikā bhāvanā svapṛthageva vaiśiṣṭyamādhatte /
analyzed: paran ca atra tad bhāvanayā sārdha gambhīra pratītyasamutpādasya samanvaya ātmikā bhāvanā sva pṛthak eva vaiśiṣṭyam ādhatte
translated: But here, by cultivating that together with the profound dependent origination, the cultivation that has the nature of connection establishes a distinctive feature of its own.

original: ittha pratyekabuddhayāne falarūpeṇa pratyekabuddhaḥ arhatpada samavāpya kāyasaketaiḥ dharma diśati /
analyzed: ittha pratyekabuddha yāne fala rūpeṇa pratyekabuddhaḥ arhat pada samavāpya kāya saketaiḥ dharma diśati
translated: Thus, in the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle, the Pratyekabuddha attains the stage of an arhat through the fruit and teaches the Dharma through bodily gestures.

original: bodhisattvayānam etadyānasya sādhako nikhiladharmeṣu nairātmya nirūpya paropakārabhāvanāyā daśapāramitāścatuḥsagrahavastūni ca samācaryya nirvikalpasamādhinā śaikṣamārge saptatriśad
analyzed: bodhisattva yānam etat yānasya sādhakaḥ nikhila dharmeṣu nairātmya nirūpya para upakāra bhāvanāyāḥ daśa pāramitāḥ catur sagraha vastūni ca samācaryya nirvikalpa samādhinā śaikṣa mārge saptatriśat
translated: This is the Bodhisattva Vehicle. The practitioner of this vehicle, having ascertained the selflessness of all phenomena, having practiced the cultivation of altruism, the ten perfections, and the four means of gathering [disciples], having attained the path of training through non-conceptual concentration,

analyzed: bodhi pākṣika dharmān bhāvayitvā aśaikṣa mārgam arthāt samantaprabhā bhūmim avāpnoti
translated: having cultivated the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, attains the path of no-more-training, the stage of universal illumination.

original: kriyātantrayānam etatsādhakaḥ kalaśamukuṭābhiṣekātparam ātmathatā paramārthataḥ catuṣkoṭirahitā viśuddhā jñātvā devatathātādiṣaṭtattvaiḥ svaya samayotpattidevasya sammukha jñānadeva samāmantrya tat svāminaḥ svaya ca dāsasya rūpeṇa samālokayati /
analyzed: kriyā tantra yānam etat sādhakaḥ kalaśa mukuṭa abhiṣekāt param paramārthataḥ catuṣkoṭi rahitā viśuddhā jñātvā samaya utpatti devasya sammukha jñānadeva samāmantrya tat svāminaḥ ca dāsasya rūpeṇa samālokayati
translated: This is the Action Tantra Vehicle. The practitioner, having received the vase and crown initiations, having realized that his own nature is ultimately free from the four extremes and pure, having understood the six realities such as the reality of the deity, having invited the wisdom deity of self-originated time in the presence of the deity, having regarded himself as the servant in the form of the master,

analyzed: śabda citta āśrayeṣu praviśya japa tathatām agni sthā
translated: having entered into the basis of sound and mind, he meditates on the reality of the mantra in the fire-abiding.

analyzed: śabda sthā śabda anta tathatā ca samādhau bhāvayati
translated: He meditates on the reality of the sound-abiding and the reality of the end of sound in concentration.

original: aya prādhānyena bāhyasnānena śucicaryayā ca trikulavajradharabhūmi prāpnoti /
analyzed: prādhānyena bāhya snānena śuci caryayā ca tri kula vajradhara bhūmi prāpnoti
translated: This, primarily through external bathing and pure conduct, he attains the stage of the vajra-holder of the three families.

original: upāyayānamarthāt caryātantrayānam etatsādhakaḥ kalaśamukuṭābhiṣekābhyā saha aṣṭamaṅgalacihna nāmābhiṣekamapi gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: upāya yānam arthāt caryā tantra yānam etad sādhakaḥ kalaśa mukuṭa abhiṣekābhyā saha nāma abhiṣekam api gṛhṇāti
translated: The vehicle of means is the vehicle of the tantra of conduct. The practitioner receives the consecration of the vase and crown, as well as the consecration named the eight auspicious symbols.

analyzed: darśanasya yoga tantrasya
translated: In accordance with the yoga tantra of the view

analyzed: caryāyāḥ ca kriyā tantrasya
translated: and the kriya tantra of conduct,

original: anusāreṇa ācāryya svaya samayotpattidevasya sammukha jñānasattvadeve bandhu mitrasama mattvā japasamādhī ca paripoṣya caturthakulavajradharabhūmivāpnoti
analyzed: anusāreṇa ācārya svayam samaya utpatti devasya sammukha jñāna sattva deve bandhu japa samādhī ca paripoṣya caturtha kula vajradhara bhūmi vāpnoti
translated: the teacher himself, considering the deity of the origin of the samaya to be a friend and equal to the wisdom being deity, and having nourished the repetition and concentration, attains the stage of the fourth family vajradhara.

original: yogatantrayānam atra sādhakaḥ vajraśiṣyābhiṣekeṇa sahācāryābhiṣekamapi gṛhṇāti paramārthataśca animittadharmatādhiṣṭhāna savṛtivajradhātudevatvena dṛṣṭvā pañcābhisambodhibhiḥ pratihāryyacatuṣṭayena ca svaya devabhāvanā vidhāya jñānasattvadevāvāhanena sāka tacca svayamātmani vilīya caturmudrāyā baddhvā pūjārcanāntara visarjana sampādya āntarikasamādhicaryāyāḥ śucyādibāhyacaryāyāḥ sevanena falarūpākaniṣṭhabhūmau paramapada samavāpnoti / mahāyogatantrayānam etadayānasya sādhakaścaturvidhābhiṣekebhyaḥ sagṛhītānuśasāsāmarthya gambhīrābhiṣekeṇopacitya mauladarśane vāstavikasādhanāyā
analyzed: atra sādhakaḥ vajra śiṣya abhiṣekeṇa saha ācārya abhiṣekam api gṛhṇāti paramārthataḥ ca animitta dharmatā adhiṣṭhāna savṛti vajradhātu deva tvena dṛṣṭvā pañca abhisambodhibhiḥ pratihārya catuṣṭayena ca svayam deva bhāvanāḥ vidhāya jñāna sattva deva āvāhanena sāka tat ca svayam ātmani vilīya catur mudrāyāḥ baddhvā pūjā arcana antara visarjana sampādya āntarika samādhi caryāyāḥ śuci ādi bāhya caryāyāḥ sevanena parama pada abhiṣe
translated: The practitioner of this vehicle, the Great Yoga Tantra Vehicle, having accumulated the merit from the four consecrations along with the power of the precepts that have been taken, by the profound consecration, for the actual practice in the main vision,

original: nikhiladharmān cittaprabhāsvaraśūnyatābhinnamahādharmakāye buddhvā mārge utpattikramaniṣpannakramayorguhyābhiṣeka samavāpya vāyutilakasya yuganaddhakramasya cābhyāsa kurvāṇaḥ ekasminneva janmani anuttarabodhi labhate /
analyzed: nikhila dharmān citta prabhāsvara śūnyatā bhinna mahā dharmakāye buddhvā mārge utpatti krama niṣpanna kramayoḥ guhya abhiṣeka samavāpya vāyu tilakasya yuga naddha kramasya ca abhyāsa kurvāṇaḥ ekasmin eva janmani anuttara bodhi labhate
translated: Having understood all dharmas as the great Dharmakaya, which is the emptiness of the luminous nature of the mind, and having received the secret abhisheka of the stages of arising and perfection on the path, practicing the yoga of the bindu of air and the yoga of the union, one attains the unsurpassed enlightenment in a single lifetime.

analyzed: atiyoga tantra yānam sādhakaḥ utra prādhānyena caturtha abhiṣekeṇa abhiṣicyate
translated: The vehicle of the tantra of excessive practice: Here the practitioner is mainly consecrated by the fourth abhisheka.

original: darśane samastabhavān nirvāṇadharmāśca ādikālatī buddhasvabhāve nirūpya cittavargopadeśanihitacaryāśca vidadhāti /
analyzed: darśane samasta bhavān nirvāṇa dharmāḥ ca buddha svabhāve nirūpya citta varga upadeśa nihita caryāḥ ca vidadhāti
translated: In the view, having ascertained all existences and nirvanic dharmas as having the nature of Buddha from the beginning, he practices the conduct taught in the chapter on the mind.

original: sarvasādhyaniṣedhebhyaḥ prahāṇagrahaṇebhyaśca uccatamaḥ san sa mārgācaraṇa kurvan samantabhadrabuddhapadamadhigacchati /
analyzed: sarva sādhya niṣedhebhyaḥ prahāṇa grahaṇebhyaḥ ca uccatamaḥ san sa mārga ācaraṇa kurvan samantabhadra buddha padam adhigacchati
translated: Being the highest among all things to be accomplished and abandoned, he attains the state of Samantabhadra Buddha by practicing the path.

original: etāni nava yānāni yadi mārgāvasthāntargatāni nirdhāryyante tadā tu yānatraya eva samāviśanti /
analyzed: etāni nava yānāni yadi mārga avasthā antargatāni nirdhāryyante tadā tu yāna trayaḥ eva samāviśanti
translated: If these nine vehicles are determined to be included within the stages of the path, then they are all included within the three vehicles.

analyzed: hīnayānam śrāvakayānam
translated: The inferior vehicle is the Shravaka vehicle.
The Bodhisattva vehicle.

analyzed: mantrayāna ca
translated: And the Mantra vehicle.

analyzed: etat yāna traya abhisamayasya uttarottara vṛddhyai a parihāryam
translated: This is unavoidable for the gradual increase of the realization of the three vehicles.

analyzed: etat vivaraṇam anyatra nirūpitam
translated: This explanation is given elsewhere.

original: upasahāraḥ vastuvādivicārakānatiricyānyasarvadharmadarśanānā vicārakāśced dārśanikānā zhazhāvāteṣu na nipatanti tarhi tattvaviṣaye sarve sthitimekā prāpnuvanti /
analyzed: upasahāraḥ vastuvādi vicārakān atiricya anya sarva dharma darśanānām vicārakāḥ ced dārśanikānām na nipatanti tarhi tattva viṣaye sarve sthitim ekā prāpnuvanti
translated: The conclusion is that if the investigators of the proponents of reality do not fall into the views of those who see all phenomena other than what is to be concluded, then they all attain stability in the truth.

original: yathā bauddhavijñānavādinaḥ viśva svacittasya vistāra mattvā cittasvarūpammanyante kimidameva citta sṛṣṭikartu nābhavat /
analyzed: yathā bauddha vijñāna vādinaḥ kim idam eva citta sṛṣṭi kartu na abhavat
translated: Just as the Buddhist Vijñānavādins, considering the universe to be an expansion of their own mind, think that the nature of mind is the creator of this world, whether this mind itself was the creator of the world or not.

original: mādhyamikāḥ vastutaḥ sarvatattvānāmekātāmaṅgīkurvanti kintadeva citta sṛṣṭerādhārabhūta na sambhāvyate /
analyzed: mādhyamikāḥ vastutas sarva tattvānām ekātām aṅgīkurvanti kintad eva sambhāvyate
translated: The Mādhyamikas accept that in reality all truths are one, but how can it be conceived that this alone is the basis of creation?

analyzed: vajrayāne tu sva kāyaḥ eva sampūrṇa brahya aṇḍam
translated: But in the Vajrayāna, the entire universe is in one's own body.

original: caturviśātipīṭhasthānānā daśabhūmīnā ca vyavasthā'pi etasminneva kāye bhavati yacca svayameva sṛṣṭikāraṇa jāyate /
analyzed: catur viśāti pīṭhasthānānām daśa bhūmīnām ca vyavasthā api etasmin eva kāye bhavati yat ca svayam eva sṛṣṭi kāraṇa jāyate
translated: The arrangement of the twenty-four sacred seats and the ten stages also occurs in this very body, which itself becomes the cause of creation.

analyzed: īśvara vādī hinduḥ vā kriścanaḥ muslimaḥ vā
translated: A Hindu who believes in God, a Christian, or a Muslim.

original: sarve'pi etat prabhāsvaracitta yacca catuṣkoṭivinirmukta niṣprapañcatattva vartate /
analyzed: sarve api etat prabhāsvara citta yat ca catuṣkoṭi vinirmukta niṣprapañca tattva vartate
translated: All of them have this luminous mind, which is the reality free from the four extremes and free from conceptual elaborations.

original: tasya bhinnanāmabhiḥ etasyaiva tattvasya vyākhyā svapaddhatyā kurvanti /
analyzed: tasya bhinna nāmabhiḥ etasya eva tattvasya vyākhyā sva paddhatyā kurvanti
translated: With different names, they explain this very reality in their own treatises.

original: cittaśamanāvasthāyām atra ko'pi bhedo na vidhātu śakyate /
analyzed: citta śamana avasthāyām atra kaḥ api bhedaḥ na vidhātu śakyate
translated: In the state of mind pacification, no distinction can be made here.

original: tenaiva sarvadharmeṣu siddhamahāpurūṣāḥ samupalabhyante iti dṛśyate'smābhiḥ /
analyzed: tena eva sarva dharmeṣu siddha mahā purūṣāḥ samupalabhyante iti dṛśyate smābhiḥ
translated: It is seen by us that those who have attained the great goal in all dharmas are found.

original: abhisamayālaṅkāre maitreyanāthaḥ prāvocat nāpaneyamataḥ kiñcit prakṣeptavya na kiñcana /
analyzed: abhisamaya alaṅkāre maitreya nāthaḥ prāvocat na apaneyam atas kiñcid prakṣeptavya na kiñcana
translated: Maitreyanatha said in the Abhisamayalankara: Nothing should be removed from this, nothing should be added.

analyzed: draṣṭavya bhūtataḥ bhūta bhūta darśī vimucyate
translated: The real should be seen as real; the one who sees the real is liberated.

original: pratyeka janaḥ svasvayogyatayā pariśrameṇa copalabdhavibhinnatattvāni nirvahan vyavahāre dhyānakṣetre ca ślokasyāsyārthānusaraṇa vidadhyāttarhi sukhī bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: pratyeka janaḥ sva sva yogyatayā pariśrameṇa ca upalabdha vibhinna tattvāni nirvahan vyavahāre dhyāna kṣetre ca vidadhyāt tarhi sukhī bhavitum arhati
translated: Each person, according to his own capacity and effort, accomplishing the various realities that are attained, should follow the meaning of this verse in the field of conventional meditation, then he deserves to be happy.

original: janaḥ sukhī bhavettarhi rāṣṭra viśva cāpi sukhi bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: janaḥ sukhī bhavet tarhi ca api sukhi bhavitum arhati
translated: Then the people will be happy, and the whole country also deserves to be happy.

analyzed: bhaviṣya vartamānasya fala bhavati
translated: The result of the present belongs to the future.

original: vartamāne śobhane sati bhaviṣyamapi samīcīna bhavati /
analyzed: vartamāne śobhane sati bhaviṣyam api bhavati
translated: When the present is beautiful, the future also becomes proper.

original: nātra saśitileśaḥ cejjīvanamida sukhamaya etatkramaśca sukhamayo varteta tahryagre kā'vaśyakatā nirvāṇasya /
analyzed: na atra sa śiti leśaḥ sukha mayaḥ etad kramaḥ ca sukha mayaḥ varteta kā āvaśyaka tā nirvāṇasya
translated: If there is no doubt here, this life is full of happiness and this process is also full of happiness, then what is the need for nirvana later?

original: āvaśyaka cedameva yadasīmitam akhaṇḍam agocara ca tattva /
analyzed: āvaśyaka ca idam eva yat asīmitam akhaṇḍam agocara ca tattva
translated: If it is necessary, then this alone is the truth which is limitless, undivided, and beyond the scope of the senses.

original: tat svabuddhiviṣaya na kuryāt nāpi ca tatra bāhyavyavasthāmādhārīkṛtya bheda kuryāt /
analyzed: tat sva buddhi viṣaya na kuryāt na api ca tatra bāhya vyavasthām ādhārīkṛtya bheda kuryāt
translated: One should not make it an object of one's own intellect, nor should one make distinctions based on external arrangements.

original: akhaṇḍatayā samabhāvena tāṭasthyena nirvikalpabhāvena ca pravartanādeva vajrayānasya vāstavika darśana tattva ca jñātu śakyate / nānyathā
analyzed: akhaṇḍa tayā sama bhāvena tāṭasthyena nirvikalpa bhāvena ca pravartanāt eva vajrayānasya vāstavika darśana tattva ca jñātu śakyate na anyathā
translated: The true view and the truth can only be known by practicing the Vajrayana itself, by remaining undivided, equal, detached, and non-conceptual, not otherwise.

original: vajrayānīyaparamparā viṣaye'smin cirakāla prāyatanta pratyakṣānubhūti cākārṣuḥ /
analyzed: vajrayānīya paramparā viṣaye ismin cira kāla prāyatanta pratyakṣa anubhūti ca akārṣuḥ
translated: The lineage of Vajrayana practitioners have long been devoted to this matter and have had direct experience.

original: naitāvadevāpi tu jīvane'sminneva sthitimimāmanubhūya nijacaramotkarṣasādhanāvidhi vyakasiṣuḥ /
analyzed: nā etāvat evā api tu jīvane ismin eva sthitim imām anubhūya nija carama utkarṣa sādhanā vidhi
translated: Not only this, but having experienced this state even in this life, they have proclaimed the method for attaining their highest state.

original: sampradāyagatabhedabuddhimapahāya nirapekṣabhāvena cenmūlyāṅkana vidhīyeta tarhi nūnameva mānavahita setsyatyasmāt /
analyzed: sampradāya gata bheda buddhim apahāya nirapekṣa bhāvena ced mūlya aṅkana vidhīyeta tarhi nūnam eva mānava hita setsyati asmāt
translated: If the valuation is done without regard, disregarding the knowledge of the divisions in the tradition, then indeed it will be beneficial for humanity.

analyzed: viśvasya tāntrika darśana sādhana apaddhateḥ nitānta āvaśyaka tva pratīyate
translated: In the fearful situation of the universe, the necessity of the means of accomplishing the Tantric view is understood to be absolute.

analyzed: āśāsyate mayā
translated: I aspire.

analyzed: mānavaḥ nija jīvane caritā arthayiṣyati
translated: That this object will be fulfilled in human life.

original: grantharacanājanyapuṇyānubhāvenāpi prāṇinaḥ samyaksambodhi prāpnuyuriti pariṇāmanā vidadhāmi /
analyzed: grantha racanā janya puṇya anubhāvena api prāṇinaḥ samyaksambodhi prāpnuyuḥ iti pariṇāmanāḥ vidadhāmi
translated: By the power of the merit generated from composing the text, I dedicate that beings may attain perfect enlightenment.

analyzed: teṣām śarīrāṇi namaskaromi tat vara citta ratnam
translated: I bow to their bodies, in which the precious jewel of the sublime mind has arisen.

analyzed: yatra apakāraḥ upi sukha anubandhī sukha ākarāḥ tān śaraṇa prayāmi
translated: Where even harm is followed by happiness, I go for refuge to those who bring happiness.

original: vaṅchukadorjenegī bhikṣuṇā praṇītā bhāratīyasaskṛtapaṇḍitadharmadattacaturvedena ca sampāditā vajrayānadarśanamīmāsākhyā kṛtiriya paripūrṇatāmagāt śubhamastu sarvajagatām / / /
analyzed: bhikṣuṇā praṇītā bhāratīya saskṛta paṇḍita dharmadatta catur vedena ca sampāditā vajra yāna darśana mīmāsā ākhyā kṛtiḥ iya paripūrṇa tām agāt śubham astu sarva jagatām  /
translated: This work called The Investigation of the Vajrayāna View was composed by the monk Vangiya Dorje and completed by the Indian scholar Dharmadāsa, who is well-versed in the four Vedas. May it be auspicious for all beings.
